Annual variable €183,300 At its meeting of 13 February 2019, the Board of Directors, on the recommendation of the Compensation compensation Committee, set the amount of the variable compensation of Xavier Musca for 2018, subject to its approval Non-deferred variable by the General Meeting of 21 May 2019. compensation In view of the achievement of financial and non-financial objectives decided by the Board at its meeting of 13 February 2018 and approved by the General Meeting of 16 May 2018, the amount of variable compensation has been determined on the following basis: nn achievement level of financial objectives: 108.2%; nn achievement level of non-financial objectives: 110%. Details of the achievement of these objectives can be found on page 158 of the Registration Document. Variable compensation earned by Xavier Musca for financial year 2018 was set at €611,000, reflecting a target achievement rate of 109.1%. This is equivalent to 87.3% of his fixed reference compensation. 30% of the variable compensation, namely €183,300 will be paid in May 2019 subject to approval by the General Meeting of 21 May 2019. Variable compensation €61,100 10% of the variable compensation, namely €61,100, is indexed to the Crédit Agricole S.A. share price and 3 indexed to the Crédit will be paid in September 2018 subject to approval by the General Meeting of 16 May 2018. Agricole S.A. share price Deferred and €366,600 60% of the variable compensation, or €366,600 at the grant date, subject to the approval of the General conditional variable Meeting of 21 May 2019, are awarded in instruments linked to the Crédit Agricole S.A. share price, compensation which vest progressively over a deferred period of three years, conditional upon the attainment of three performance targets. Details of the principle used to measure these objectives can be found on pages 155 and 165 of the Registration Document. Long-term variable No payment Xavier Musca was not awarded any stock options or performance shares or any other long-term compensation for 2018 compensation for 2018. Exceptional No payment Xavier Musca received no exceptional compensation for 2018. compensation for 2018 Directors’ fees No payment Xavier Musca waived receipt of Directors’ fees for the duration of his term of office as Director of Group for 2018 companies. Benefits in kind No benefits Xavier Musca did not receive any benefits in kind. in kind Elements of compensation paid or awarded for the financial year ended, submitted for the approval of shareholders and that were voted on by the General Meeting as part of the procedure governing related party agreements and commitments Amount Presentation Severance payment No payment Xavier Musca will receive severance payment if Crédit Agricole S.A. terminates his employment contract for 2018 under the conditions approved by the Board of Directors at its meeting on 19 May 2015 and ratified by the General Meeting of 19 May 2016. Non-competition No payment In the event of termination of his office as Deputy Chief Executive Officer, on any grounds whatsoever, compensation for 2018 Xavier Musca may be bound by a non-competition clause for a period of one year from the date of termination, as approved by the Board at its meeting on 19 May 2015 and ratified by the General Meeting 19 May 2016. Supplementary No payment No supplementary pension benefit is payable to Xavier Musca for financial year 2018, in accordance pension for 2018 with the provisions of Article L. 225-37-3-3 of the French Commercial Code, Xavier Musca’s annual and conditional individual supplementary pension entitlements as at 31 December 2018 include: nn a life annuity under a defined-contribution supplementary pension scheme, for an estimated gross amount of €4,000; nn a life annuity under a defined-benefit supplementary pension scheme, for an estimated gross amount of €83,000. The uncertain entitlements under the defined-benefit supplementary pension scheme are subject to continued employment at retirement and are estimated on the basis of 6.5 years’ service recorded on the closing date, corresponding to 7.4% of the reference compensation at 31/12/2018, i.e. a 1.1% increase in contingent rights compared with 2017. On that basis, the provisions of Article L. 225-42-1 of the French Commercial Code, as amended under law No. 2015-990 of 6 August 2015 for growth, activity and equal economic opportunities, limiting the annual increase in contingent rights to 3% have been met.The published estimated amounts are the gross amounts before taxes and social security charges applicable at the reporting period end date, particularly income tax payable by individuals and supplementary contributions of 7% and 14%, payable by the beneficiary, which are deducted from the life annuities payable under the defined-benefit supplementary pension scheme. Details of these schemes can be found on pages 155 and 156 of the Registration Document. The definitions of the underlined words can be found in the Glossary on page 600. Corporate governance 4. Reward policy Apportionment and award criteria for elements of compensation for the Chief Executive Officer Presentation Fixed compensation The fixed annual compensation of the Chief Executive Officer has been €1,100,000 since May 2018. There are no plans to change this in 2019. Annual variable compensation The Chief Executive Officer has a target annual variable compensation of 100% of his fixed compensation, capped at 120% if performance exceeds the target. The performance assessment linked to the annual variable compensation is 50% based on financial criteria and 50% on non-financial criteria. At its meeting on 13 February 2019, the Board of Directors set four financial criteria: Weighting Threshold Target Ceiling Revenues (NBI) 12.5% 80% 100% 150% Net Income Group share 12.5% 80% 100% 150% 50% Cost/income ratio 12.5% 80% 100% 150% Return on tangible equity 12.5% 80% 100% 150% The financial criteria relate to the scope of Crédit Agricole S.A. Group. For each of these, the target is set on the basis of the budget approved by the Board of Directors at its meeting on 13 February 2019. These criteria each account for one-quarter of the financial portion, i.e. one-eighth of annual variable compensation and for each criterion: nn the maximum achievement rate cannot exceed 150%; 3 nn a trigger threshold is applied, below which the achievement rate will be considered zero. Performance between the trigger threshold and target as well as between the target and ceiling is calculated on a straight-line basis. The non-financial criteria are determined each year on the basis of the Group’s strategic priorities. In keeping with the previous year and in terms of the ambitions of the Medium-Term Plan, “Ambition 2020”, the Board of Directors meeting on 13 February 2019 selected four sets of objectives for 2019: nn the finalisation of the Crédit Agricole Group’s Medium-Term Plan “Strategic Ambition 2020” (17.5%); nn the Group’s transformation in order to improve operational efficiency (10%); nn the steering of control functions in view of tighter regulation (10%); nn employee engagement with the Crédit Agricole Group (12.5%). The achievement rate of non-financial criteria cannot exceed 150%. Performance is assessed for each indicator, by comparing results achieved with the annual targets defined by the Board of Directors. Long-term variable compensation The Chief Executive Officer is not eligible for stock option plans or performance share awards or any other long-term compensation or multi-annual variable compensation scheme for 2019. Exceptional compensation There are no plans at present to award the Chief Executive Officer exceptional compensation for 2019. Directors’ fees The Chief Executive Officer waived receipt of Directors’ fees for the duration of his term of office as Director of Group companies. Benefits in kind The Chief Executive Officer does not receive any benefits in kind. Under the commitments authorised by the Board of Directors on nn non-competition compensation if a non-competition clause is 19 May 2015 and approved by the General Meeting of 19 May 2016 and triggered, for a period of one year from the termination of his office, as described on pages 155 to 157 of this document, the Chief Executive regardless of the cause; Officer receives: nn the supplementary pension scheme for executive managers of Crédit nn severance payment in the event that his office is terminated by Crédit Agricole Group, which supplements the collective and mandatory Agricole S.A.; pension and death & disability schemes. The definitions of the underlined words can be found in the Glossary on page 600. CRÉDIT AGRICOLE S.A. | 2018 Registration Document 163 3 Corporate governance 4. Reward policy Criteria for apportioning and awarding elements of compensation for the Deputy Chief Executive Officer Presentation Fixed compensation The annual fixed compensation of the Deputy Chief Executive Officer has been €700,000 since 19 May 2015. There are no plans to change this in 2019. Annual variable compensation The Deputy Chief Executive Officer has a target annual variable compensation of 80% of his fixed compensation, capped at 120% if performance exceeds the target. The performance assessment linked to the annual variable compensation is 50% based on financial criteria and 50% on non-financial criteria. At its meeting on 13 February 2019, the Board of Directors set four financial criteria: Weighting Threshold Target Ceiling Revenues (NBI) 12.5% 80% 100% 150% Net Income Group share 12.5% 80% 100% 150% 50% Cost/income ratio 12.5% 80% 100% 150% Return on tangible equity 12.5% 80% 100% 150% The financial criteria relate to the scope of Crédit Agricole S.A. Group. For each of these, the target is set on the basis of the budget approved by the Board of Directors at its meeting on 13 February 2019. These criteria each account for one-quarter of the financial portion, i.e. one-eighth of annual variable compensation and for each criterion: nn the maximum achievement rate cannot exceed 150%; nn a trigger threshold is applied, below which the achievement rate will be considered zero. Performance between the trigger threshold and target as well as between the target and ceiling is calculated on a straight-line basis. The non-financial criteria are determined each year on the basis of the Group’s strategic priorities. In keeping with the previous year and in terms of the ambitions of the Medium-Term Plan, “Ambition 2020”, the Board of Directors meeting on 13 February 2019 selected four sets of objectives for 2019: nn the finalisation of the Crédit Agricole Group’s Medium-Term Plan “Strategic Ambition 2020” (7.5%); nn the Group’s transformation in order to improve operational efficiency (17.5%); nn the steering of control functions in view of tighter regulation (17.5%); nn employee engagement with the Crédit Agricole Group (7.5%). The achievement rate of non-financial criteria cannot exceed 150%. Performance is assessed for each indicator, by comparing results achieved with the annual targets defined by the Board of Directors. The Deputy Chief Executive Officer’s performance assessment is presented to the Compensation Committee by the Chief Executive Officer, before being presented to the Board of Directors for decision. Long-term variable compensation The Deputy Chief Executive Officer is not eligible for stock option plans or performance share awards or any other long-term compensation or multi-annual variable compensation scheme for 2019. Exceptional compensation There are no plans at present to award the Deputy Chief Executive Officer exceptional compensation for 2019. Directors’ fees The Deputy Chief Executive Officer waived receipt of Directors’ fees for the duration of his term of office as Director of Group companies. Benefits in kind The Deputy Chief Executive Officer does not receive any benefits in kind. Under the commitments authorised by the Board of Directors on nn non-competition compensation if a non-competition clause is 19 May 2015 and approved by the General Meeting of 19 May 2016 and triggered, for a period of one year from the termination of his office, as described on pages 155 to 157 of this document, the Deputy Chief regardless of the cause; Executive Officer receives: nn the supplementary pension scheme for executive managers of Crédit nn severance payment in the event that his office is terminated by Crédit Agricole Group, which supplements the collective and mandatory Agricole S.A.; pension and death & disability schemes. 164 CRÉDIT AGRICOLE S.A. | 2018 Registration Document The definitions of the underlined words can be found in the Glossary on page 600. Reward policy Asset management Credit institutions and investment companies(1) companies Insurance companies Identified staff nn employees with authorisation or powers to take credit risk of more Additional condition: by virtue of than 0.5% of Common Equity Tier 1 (CET1) capital in the subsidiary to Those who earn variable their level of which they belong and of at least €5 million, or with authorisation or compensation of more than authorisation or powers to structure this type of product with a significant impact on €100,000. compensation the risk profile of the subsidiary to which they belong; nn employees who can take market risks of more than 0.5% of the CET1 capital or 5% of the Value at Risk (VaR) of the subsidiary to which they belong; nn the hierarchical managers of employees who are not individually identified but who are collectively authorised to take credit risks of more than 0.5% of CET1 capital in the subsidiary to which they belong and at least €5 million, or to take market risks of more than 0.5% of the CET1 capital or 5% of the Value at Risk (VaR) of the subsidiary to which they belong; nn employees who have earned total gross compensation of more than €500,000 in the previous financial year; nn employees who are not identified under any of the previous criteria but whose total compensation puts them in the 0.3% top earners in the entity in the previous year (for entities with a balance sheet of more than €10 billion or with equity of more than 2% of their parent company’s equity). Characteristics In view of the proportionality principle, employees whose bonus or Total variable Deferred The deferred of deferred variable compensation is less than €120,000 are excluded from the compensation portion compensation compensation scope of application of rules on deferred compensation in all Group for year Y framework is the entities, unless otherwise stipulated by the regulatory authorities in < €100,000 Not applicable same as that of the countries in which the Group’s subsidiaries are located. credit institutions and The deferred portion is determined based on the overall variable €100,00050% from the investment companies, compensation awarded for the financial year. €600,000 first euro unless the portion of the > €600,000 60% from non-deferred variable Total variable compensation Deferred portion the first euro compensation granted for year Y with minimum in shares or sharenon-deferred linked instruments as < €120,000 Not applicable amount of well as the application €300,000 of a retention period, €120,000-€400,000 40% from the first euro that is not required. €400,000-€600,000 50% from the first euro with minimum non-deferred amount of €240,000 > €600,000 60% from the first euro with minimum non-deferred amount of €300,000 Payment in securities or equivalent instruments The deferred variable compensation and a percentage of the non-deferred portion carried for six months are granted in the form of Crédit Agricole S.A. shares or share-linked instruments. As a result, at least 50% of variable compensation for identified staff is awarded in shares or equivalent instruments. Any hedging or insurance strategies limiting the scope of alignment provisions on risks contained in the compensation scheme are prohibited. Performance conditions The deferred portion is vested in thirds: for an award in year Y, one third in year Y+1, one third in year Y+2 and one third in year Y+3, provided the vesting criteria are met. Each vesting date is followed by a six-month retention period. The performance conditions for executive managers and identified employees are aligned with those for long-term variable compensation as indicated in the “Long-Term Variable Compensation” paragraph of Chapter 4.2.2 “Elements of reward of executive managers”. For other identified staff, the performance conditions are determined relative to the target net income Group share for the entity, which is determined during the year in which the variable compensation under consideration is awarded. (1) The credit institutions and investment companies concerned are those covered by the scope of application of the Decree of 3 November 2014 on the internal control of credit institutions and investment companies. For the Group, this concerns Crédit Agricole S.A. along with all entities whose balance sheet total is greater than €10 billion, or whose shareholders’ equity exceeds 2% of the equity of their parent company. 170 CRÉDIT AGRICOLE S.A. | 2018 Registration Document The definitions of the underlined words can be found in the Glossary on page 600. Corporate governance 5. Rules of Procedure of the Board of Directors CRÉDIT AGRICOLE S.A. DIRECTORS’ CODE OF CONDUCT The purpose of this Code of Conduct is to contribute to the quality of the Article 5 – Performance of duties: Guidelines Directors’ work by encouraging them to apply the principles and best practices of corporate governance. Directors must act independently, fairly, professionally and with integrity in the performance of their duties. Crédit Agricole S.A. Directors undertake to abide by the guidelines contained in this Code and to implement them. Article 6 – Independence and duty to speak out Article 1 – Corporate administration and interests Directors must ensure that they retain their independence and freedom of judgement, decision and action in all circumstances. They must be Directors, regardless of how they are appointed, must consider impartial and undertake not to be influenced by any factor that may be themselves as representing all shareholders and other stakeholders detrimental to the corporate interests that they are bound to defend. and must act in their interests and in the Company’s interests under all circumstances. They should disclose to the Board any matter that may come to their attention and that they deem to be a potential threat to the Company’s Article 2 – Compliance with the law and Articles interests. of Association They are duty bound to clearly express their questions and opinions. In the event that they disagree, they should request that their objections be When Directors first assume their office and throughout their term of expressly recorded in the minutes of the meeting. office, they must be fully conversant with their general and/or special rights and obligations. They must know and comply with the legal and Article 7 – Independence and conflict of interests 3 regulatory provisions applicable to the Company and to their office, the applicable Codes of Governance and Best Practice, as well as the Directors shall inform the Board of any conflict of interest, including Company’s own rules as set out in the Articles of Association and Rules any potential conflict of interest, that they could be directly or indirectly of Procedure. involved in. They shall refrain from participating in related discussions and the vote on the corresponding resolution. Article 3 – Attention and Diligence Article 8 – Integrity, fairness and propriety Directors shall dedicate the necessary time, care and attention to their duties. Directors shall act in good faith in all circumstances and shall not do anything that could be detrimental to the interests of the Company or Directors must comply with the legal and regulatory provisions applicable other Crédit Agricole Group companies. to Directors of credit institutions. The Directors personally undertake to keep confidential all information To this end, upon taking up office, Directors must inform the Chairman received, all discussions in which they participate, and all decisions of the Board of all offices held in other companies, along with the name made. and legal form of the entities in which these offices are held. Directors must demonstrate sufficient honesty, integrity and Directors must inform the Chairman of the Board, in a timely manner, independence of mind to enable them to assess and, where necessary, of any change (termination, resignation, non-renewal, redundancy, new question the decisions of Executive Management and ensure the office) to the declared list of offices. supervision and effective monitoring of management decision-making. Directors undertake to resign their offices if they feel they are no longer in a position to carry out their duties on the Board and on the Specialised Article 9 – Inside information – insider trading Committees on which they sit. Unless genuinely unable to do so, they must diligently attend and actively Directors shall not use inside information to which they have access for participate in all meetings of the Board and of any Committees on which their personal gain or for the gain of any other person. they may sit. Crédit Agricole S.A. shares and related financial Article 4 – Information and training instruments: Directors aware of non-public information regarding the Company in The Chairman ensures that all relevant information and documents are which they exercise their term of office shall refrain from using such made available to the Directors in sufficient time to properly carry out information to engage in trading in Crédit Agricole S.A. shares, whether their duties. Likewise, the Chairman of each Specialised Committee directly or through a third party. They are thus added to the list of ensures that all relevant information and documents are made available “Permanent Insiders” with respect to Crédit Agricole S.A. shares made to the Directors in sufficient time to properly carry out their duties. available to the French financial markets authority (Autorité des marchés Directors, regardless of their experience, have a responsibility to remain financiers, AMF). informed and acquire knowledge on an ongoing basis. They must keep They undertake to comply with the rules that stipulate that “Permanent themselves informed so as to be able to give full consideration to the Insiders” may trade in Crédit Agricole S.A. shares within a period of six matters covered in the meeting agenda. weeks following the release of quarterly, half-yearly and annual results, To this end, Crédit Agricole S.A. allocates the necessary human and provided that, during such periods, they are not aware of any non-public financial resources to train Directors and the latter are required to information on the Company. dedicate the necessary time to the training offered by Crédit Agricole S.A. They receive a letter notifying them of these obligations from the Directors are made aware of any legislative and regulatory changes, Compliance department of Crédit Agricole S.A., which they must including those relating to inside information. acknowledge. CRÉDIT AGRICOLE GROUP CODE OF ETHICS This new code of ethics expresses Crédit Agricole Group’s commitment Our long-standing values, close customer relationships, responsibility to behaviour that reflects all its values and principles of action vis-à-vis and solidarity mean that people drive our actions and are central to our its customers, mutual shareholders, shareholders, as well as its suppliers purpose. and all stakeholders with whom it engages. It acts as a responsible Crédit Agricole promotes the cooperative values of democratic employer. governance, relationships of trust and respect for and between its It is the responsibility of Directors and executives to respect the values set members. It relies on each person’s sense of responsibility and out in this Code and to set an example. Executives must ensure that these entrepreneurial spirit. Customer satisfaction, regional development and values are applied and shared by all Crédit Agricole Group employees, the search for long-term performance inform its actions. regardless of their level of responsibility, business line or place of work. Our identity and values require each person to act in an irreproachable Our code of ethics, beyond merely applying all the legal, regulatory and manner. Each Group entity shares the belief that these values drive industry rules governing our various businesses, reflects our desire to strength and growth. do even more to better serve our customers, who have been our raison Built on its sense of ethics and fairness and true to its cooperative culture, d’être since day one. compliance helps enhance customer trust and the Group’s image. It is All Directors and employees are made aware of our code of ethics. central to our business lines and to the governance of Crédit Agricole It is applied by each entity in a form that reflects its specific characteristics Group. and incorporated into its internal control procedures. Crédit Agricole Group undertakes that its principles of action help further The Compliance principles are compiled into a set of rules (Fides). its goal of being the fair bank, open to everyone, multi-channel, providing each person with support over time and with the ability to make fully Our principles of action and behaviour comply with the fundamental informed decisions. principles found in the various international documents(1). Our identity and values Our principles of action apply Vis-à-vis our customers Crédit Agricole Group is built around regional cooperative and mutual banks, with a European calling and open to the world. Over the first nine months, the increase was fuelled by production cuts by OPEC, a collapse in production in Venezuela and the return of US sanctions on Iranian oil exports. A temporary halt in production cuts by OPEC and Russia combined with a sharp increase in production in the US sparked a tumble in the price during the last quarter of 2018. It indicates the portion of profit attributable to each share (not the portion of earnings paid out to each shareholder, which is the dividend). It may decrease, with total profit unchanged, if the number of shares increases. CRÉDIT AGRICOLE S.A. | 2018 Registration Document 205 5 Risks and Pillar 3 1. Risk factors 1. RISK FACTORS This part of the management report sets out the main types of risks Within each category, the risks that the Crédit Agricole S.A. group to which the Crédit Agricole S.A. group is exposed, as well as certain currently considers to be most significant, based on an assessment risks related to holding securities of Crédit Agricole S.A. Other parts of of likelihood of occurrence and potential impact, are presented first. this chapter discuss the Crédit Agricole S.A. group’s risk appetite and However, even a risk that is currently considered to be less important the policies employed to manage these risks. The Crédit Agricole S.A. group is subject to cyber risk, which is the risk caused by a malicious and/or fraudulent act, perpetrated digitally in an effort to manipulate data (personal, banking/insurance, technical or strategic data), processes and users, with the aim of causing material losses to companies, their employees, partners and customers. Cyber risk has become a top priority in the field of operational risks. MAJOR RISKS TAXONOMY To ensure a consistent understanding of risk categories, the Group maintains an internal taxonomy of major risks. This taxonomy is reviewed and validated at least annually by the Executive Committee or Risk Committee. A risk is considered to be major when its occurrence results in a significant deviation from the profit, solvency or liquidity objectives for a Group 5 activity or entity. The notion of major risk is defined either when the impact has already been observed historically, or when it is a risk considered minor until now but could, under certain circumstances, materialise at a much higher level than what can currently be observed. This notion can also include emerging risks related to new activities. Type of risk Definition Credit risks Global Credit Risk Risk incurred in the event of default by a counterparty or counterparties that are considered to be a same group of related customers. NB: for corporate debt securities in the investment portfolio, Global Credit Risk includes the risk of default by the issuer but not the spread risk, which is classified as Issuer Risk. Sectoral and individual Risk arising from exposure to each counterparty, including central counterparties, to counterparties considered Concentration risk to be the same group of related customers, to counterparties operating in the same economic sector or geographic area, or from the provision of credit for the same activity, or from the application of credit risk mitigation techniques, in particular security interests issued by the same issuer. Country and Sovereign Risk The risk of concentration of exposures in the credit and investment portfolios from the country or sovereign component. NB: For sovereign debt securities in the investment portfolio, Country and Sovereign Risk includes the risk of default by the issuer, but not the spread risk, which is classified as Issuer Risk. Retail Banking risks – Credit risk on the specific area of retail banking in France. France Retail Banking risks – Credit risk on the specific area of retail banking abroad. International Counterparty Risk on Market Risk incurred in the event of default or deterioration in the credit quality of a counterparty or counterparties transactions considered as the same group of related customers, on transactions processed in the trading book (securities, derivatives, etc.). Securitisation Risk Credit risk arising from securitisation transactions in which the reporting company acts as an investor, initiator or sponsor, including reputational risks such as those arising in connection with complex structures or products. The definitions of the underlined words can be found in the Glossary on page 600. CRÉDIT AGRICOLE S.A. | 2018 Registration Document 215 5 Risks and Pillar 3 2. Major risks taxonomy Type of risk Definition Settlement Risk Delivery Scope: any transaction requiring the cross-exchange of debt securities, shares, currencies or commodities, provided that such exchange is neither subject to a bilateral netting agreement nor carried out via a third party guaranteeing delivery (or payment) to both counterparties against payment. The risk arises when a counterparty fails to deliver the debt securities, shares, currencies or commodities it owes at the end of a transaction, whereas the Bank has already delivered to it the debt securities, shares, currencies or commodities that the Bank owed it on the same transaction. The risk base is the gross equivalent value of securities, shares, currencies or commodities to be received from a given counterparty on the same due date. Financial risks Equity Risk/Investment risk Risk of a decrease in the value of equity investments (of any type, including listed shares, unlisted shares, etc.) made with the aim of influencing the Company’s administration, whether they are securities “the long-term ownership of which is considered useful to the Company’s business, in particular because it enables it to influence or control the Company issuing the securities”, or equity investments in the context of a private equity activity. Market risk Scope: trading portfolios (excluding equity and investment portfolios). Risk of losses on onand off-balance sheet positions resulting from changes in market prices (also includes equity risk in this portfolio). Issuer Risk Risk of a decrease in the value of securities held in the banking book and recorded at fair value, the acquisition of which is carried out in order to generate a return and/or manage liquidity reserves. This risk is materialised by the decrease in the value of the financial asset linked to changes in the issuer’s credit quality for debt securities (CSRBB – Credit Spread Risk in the Banking Book) or by the decrease in the share price for listed shares. Foreign exchange risk Risk arising from operational foreign exchange positions (including trading and securities portfolios) and structural foreign exchange positions (equity investments): nn impact on P&L of operational foreign exchange positions left open; nn impact on equity of structural exchange rate positions left open. Liquidity risk Risk of not having sufficient funds to meet commitments. This risk is assessed and monitored as part of the ILAAP process. Global Interest Rate Risk Risk of loss on future net interest margin due to interest rate stress. Risk of excessive leverage Risk of vulnerability of an institution resulting from potential leverage or leverage that may require corrective measures to be taken in the event of losses or financing difficulties of the institution, such as an emergency sale of assets that may result in additional losses or a downward revaluation of the remaining assets. Operational risks and associated risks Other Operational Risks From a general perspective, the risk of loss resulting from shortcomings or failure in internal procedures, staff, information systems or external events; operational risk includes in particular risks related to events with a low probability of occurrence but a high impact. Non-compliance risk/ nn Risk of judicial, administrative or disciplinary sanction, significant financial loss or damage to reputation arising Misconduct risk/ from non-compliance with provisions specific to banking and financial activities: Legal risk nn current or potential risk of loss for an institution resulting from the inappropriate provision of financial services, including cases of wilful or negligent misconduct; this includes the risks of non-compliance with customers, products, business practices and the risk of internal fraud; nn risk of any dispute with a counterparty, resulting from any imprecision, deficiency or insufficiency that may be attributable to the reporting entity in respect of its operations. Model risk Model risk is the risk of loss resulting from the use of inadequate models for price calculation, revaluation, position hedging, or risk management purposes, due either to the quality of the data used, the modelling technique, the implementation or the use of these. Accounting risk Risk related to the quality of banking and financial information, whether intended for effective managers or the supervisory body, transmitted to regulatory and supervisory authorities or included in documents to be published. Information Systems Security Risks inherent to security, continuity of information systems and integrity and confidentiality of information. Risks External risk (cyberspace) of which telecommunication systems and means are the vectors – National Institute of Standards and Technology (NIST) definition. Physical Risk: Safety, Security, Risks inherent to the safety of personnel, work tools and equipment. Prevention Other risks Business related and strategic Risk related to losses, revenue or income decreases due to decisions related to strategic choices risk and/or competitive positioning. Systemic (macro-economic Overall risk related to the macroeconomic, political and regulatory environment (particularly prudential and fiscal). environment) and regulatory risk Insurance Risk Underwriting risk, provisioning risk and reinsurance risk. Conglomerate risk Aggregate of specific risks borne by a financial conglomerate. Climate risk (physical and First level risks that may arise as a result of climatic events (floods, storms). energy transition) Risk resulting from the transition to a less carbon-intensive economy. This risk factor mainly pertains to the evolution of the price of financial assets exposed to carbon. 216 CRÉDIT AGRICOLE S.A. | 2018 Registration Document The definitions of the underlined words can be found in the Glossary on page 600. Risks and Pillar 3 3. Risk management 3. RISK MANAGEMENT This section of the management report presents the Group’s risk In order to cover all risks inherent in the banking business, additional appetite, the nature of the main risks to which the Group is exposed, information is provided concerning: their magnitude and the measures implemented to manage them. nn operational risks; The information presented under IFRS 7 on financial instrument nn legal risks; disclosures covers the following main types of risks(1): nn non-compliance risks. nn credit risks; In accordance with legislation and best professional practices, risk nn market risks; management within Crédit Agricole S.A. Group is reflected by a form of nn structural balance sheet risks: global interest rate risk, foreign governance in which the roles and responsibilities of each individual are exchange risk and et liquidity risk, including risks associated with clearly identified, as well as by effective and reliable risk management the insurance industry. methodologies and procedures which make it possible to measure, supervise and manage all the risks to which the Group is exposed. 3.1. INTERNAL CONTROL AND RISK MANAGEMENT PROCEDURES Crédit Agricole Group’s internal control organization reflects an I. References in terms of internal control architecture in line with legal and regulatory requirements, as well as the recommendations of the Basel Committee. References to internal control are based on the provisions of the French Monetary and Financial Code(1), the Decree of 3 November 2014 on The internal control system and procedures are defined within the Crédit internal control of companies in the banking, payment services and Agricole Group as all systems designed to control activities and risks of investment services sector subject to control by the Autorité de contrôle all kinds and to ensure regularity (in the sense of compliance with laws, prudentiel et de résolution (ACPR), the AMF General Regulation and the regulations and internal standards), safety and efficiency of operations, recommendations on internal control, risk management and solvency in accordance with the references presented in section 1 below. issued by the Basel Committee. For the large customer category, a single fifteen-grade rating scale has been established on the basis of a segmentation of risk so as to provide a uniform view of default risk “over a full business cycle”. It has 13 ratings (A+ to E-) categorising counterparties not in default and two ratings (F and Z) categorising counterparties in default. This risk does not differ in nature from “elementary” risk (credit, market 3.1 Process for monitoring concentrations by counterparty or group of related counterparties and operational risks), but is an aggregate of risks resulting from vulnerability to a specific political, social, macroeconomic and financial The consolidated commitments of all Crédit Agricole Group entities are environment. MARKET RISK Market risk is the risk of a negative impact on the income statement I. Objectives and policy or balance sheet of adverse fluctuations in the value of financial instruments following changes in market parameters, particularly: Crédit Agricole S.A. Group has a specific market risk management nn interest rates: interest rate risk is the risk of a change in the fair value of a financial instrument or the future cash flows from a financial system with its own organisation independent of operational hierarchies, risk identification and measurement methods, monitoring 5 and consolidation procedures. In terms of scope, this system hedges instrument due to a change in interest rates; all market risk. nn exchange rates: foreign exchange risk is the risk of a change in the fair value of a financial instrument due to a change in exchange rates; In a market still marked by persistently low rates, economic uncertainties and global geopolitical tensions (post-Brexit discussions, nn prices: price risk is the risk of a change or volatility in the price of Italian government policies Sino-American trade tensions and central equities, commodities, baskets of equities or stock market indices. bank monetary policy guidelines), the Crédit Agricole Group continued The instruments most exposed to this risk are, in particular, variableto apply a prudent market risk management policy, in line with its risk income securities, equity derivatives and commodity derivatives; appetite. nn credit spreads: credit risk is the risk of a change in the fair value of a financial instrument resulting from movement in the credit spreads on indices or issuers. For more complex credit products there is also the risk of a change in fair value arising from a change in correlation between issuer defaults. The definitions of the underlined words can be found in the Glossary on page 600. CRÉDIT AGRICOLE S.A. | 2018 Registration Document 235 5 Risks and Pillar 3 3. Risk management II. Risks and Pillar 3 3. Risk management 1.1 VaR (Value at Risk) The VaR calculation methodology undergoes constant improvement The central element of the market risk measurement system is the Value and adjustment to take into account, among other things, the changing at Risk (VaR). VaR can be defined as the maximum theoretical loss on a sensitivity of positions to risk factors and the relevance of the methods portfolio in the event of adverse movements in market parameters over to new market conditions. For example, efforts are made to incorporate a given timeframe and for a given confidence interval. Crédit Agricole new risk factors and to achieve finer granularity on existing risk factors. S.A. Group uses a confidence interval of 99% and a timeframe of one day using one year of historical data. In this way, market risks incurred Limitations of the historical VaR calculation by the Group in its trading activities can be monitored on a daily basis by The main methodological limitations of the VaR model are the following: quantifying the estimated maximum level of loss in 99 out of 100 cases, nn the use of daily shocks assumes that all positions can be liquidated or after inclusion of a number of risk factors (interest rate, exchange rate, covered in one day, which is not always the case for certain products asset prices, etc.). or in certain crisis situations; The offsetting figure is defined as the difference between total VaR and nn the use of a 99% confidence interval excludes losses that could occur the sum of VaRs by risk factor. It represents the effects of diversification outside of that interval: VaR is consequently an indicator of risk under among positions held simultaneously on different risk factors. A normal market conditions and does not take into account movements procedure known as back-testing (comparing each day’s result against of exceptional magnitude; VaR estimated the day before) is used to confirm the relevance of the nn VaR does not provide any information on amounts of exceptional methodology. losses (beyond the 99% confidence interval). Risk management 1.2 Stress scenarios nn hypothetical scenarios anticipating plausible shocks, which are Stress scenarios complement the VaR measure, which does not developed in conjunction with economists. The hypothetical capture the impact of extreme market conditions. Stress scenarios scenarios used are economic recovery with rising equity and are calculated following Group principles to simulate extreme market commodity markets, flattening yield curves, appreciation of the USD conditions and are the result of different complementary approaches: and narrowing credit spreads; liquidity crunch, with flattening yield nn historical scenarios, which consist in replicating the impact on the curves, widening spreads, falling equity markets; and international current portfolio of major crises observed in the past. The past crises tensions (scenario representing economic conditions in a context of used in historical stress scenarios are the 1987 stock market crash, international tensions between China and the United States: rising the 1994 bond market crisis, the 1998 credit market crisis, coupled volatility and falling prices on the equity markets, falling futures with falling equity markets, sharply rising interest rates and declining prices and rising volatility on the commodities market, flattening emerging-country currencies; the 2008 crisis following the failure yield curves, fall of the USD against other currencies, widening credit of Lehman Brothers (two stress scenarios measuring the impact of spreads). market movements after the failure); The stress scenarios are calculated weekly. At year-end 2018, the risk levels of Crédit Agricole S.A. Group assessed through historical and hypothetical stress scenarios were presented below. As an illustration, the scenario “International tensions” which was negative at end-2017 (loss of €6.4 million) has a positive impact at end-2018 (gains of €41 billion). These related to the risk of default and migration on so-called linear credit include indicators of sensitivity to various risk factors, loss alerts, positions (i.e. not including credit correlation positions), required by the stop-loss indicators, nominal amounts, outstandings, remaining terms, CRD4 directive. etc. These indicators provide fine-grained measurements of exposure to different market risk factors, serve to identify atypical transactions Its purpose is to quantify any unexpected losses caused by credit events and fill out the summary picture of risks supplied by VaR and global on the issuers, i.e. default and migration of rating (the case of either a stress scenarios. fall or a rise in credit rating). Group’s exposure to global interest rate risk. II. Global interest rate risk 3. Measurement and management system 1. Objectives 3.1 Measurement The objective of global interest rate risk management is to stabilise the The rate risk measurement is mainly based on the calculation of rate future profits of Group entities against the impact of any adverse interest gaps or impasses. rate movements. This methodology consists of creating future projections of outstandings Changes in interest rates impact net interest income by creating at known rates and inflation-indexed outstandings according to their mismatches in timing or in the type of indexation between assets and contractual features (maturity date, amortisation profile) or by modelling sources of funds. Interest rate risk management uses balance sheet or out flows of outstandings where: off-balance sheet transactions to limit the resulting volatility in income. nn the maturity profile is not known (products with no contractual The scope for monitoring the global interest rate risk is made up of maturity, such as demand deposits, passbook accounts or capital); entities whose business generates an interest rate risk: nn implicit options sold to customers are incorporated (early loan nn Regional Banks; repayments, home purchase savings, etc.). nn LCL group; These models are usually defined based on a statistical analysis of past nn Crédit Agricole S.A.; customer behaviour coupled with a qualitative analysis (economic and regulatory context, commercial strategy, etc.). nn International retail banks, in particular the CA Italia; nn Crédit Agricole Corporate and Investment Bank; Consistency between the models used by the Group’s various entities is ensured by the fact that the models must adhere to the modelling nn Crédit Agricole Consumer Finance group; principles approved by the Standards and Methodology Committee. nn Crédit Agricole Leasing & Factoring group; They are approved by the entity’s ALM Committee and their relevance nn CACEIS; is monitored on an annual basis. nn Amundi. The gaps are consolidated quarterly at Group level. ALM Committee, which is chaired by the Chief Executive Officer. General decisions on how to manage Foreign exchange risk is treated differently depending on whether positions are taken during these meetings. the change in currency position is structural (re-evaluated by OCI) or operational (re-evaluated by P&L). 2. Operational foreign exchange risk 1. Structural foreign exchange risk Operational foreign exchange risk arises from income and expenses of all kinds that are denominated in currencies other than the euro (provisions, The Group’s structural foreign exchange risk arises from long-term net income generated by foreign subsidiaries and branches, dividends in investments by the Group in assets denominated in foreign currencies foreign currencies, etc.), and from balance sheet imbalances. (equity of the foreign operating entities, whether resulting from acquisitions, transfers of funds from the head office, or capitalisation Crédit Agricole S.A. manages the positions affected by foreign currency of local earnings), with the Group’s reference currency being the euro. revenues and expenses that appear on its books, as does each entity within the Group that bears significant risk. The Foreign Subsidiaries’ At 31 December 2018, the Group’s main structural foreign currency Treasury departments manage their operational foreign exchange risk positions, on a gross basis before hedging, are in US dollars and currencies in their local currency. pegged to the dollar (in particular the Saudi Rial), in pounds sterling, Swiss francs, Polish zlotys, Moroccan dirhams and Japanese yen. The Group’s general policy is to limit its operational currency positions and not to hedge revenues that have not yet materialised, unless The main principles of structural currency position management are: there is a strong probability that losses will materialise and unless the nn over the next year, the coverage of the portion of structural positions impairment risk is high. that are expected to become operational positions (results in the process of being formed that are expected to be distributed, shares In accordance with the foreign exchange risk monitoring and that are expected to be sold in the near future). management procedures, operational currency exposure positions are updated monthly or daily for foreign exchange trading operations. (1) In line with the Group decision, Crédit Agricole S.A. Group does not apply the “hedge accounting” option under IFRS 9. All hedging relationships continue to be documented in accordance with the rules in IAS 39, until, at the latest, the date of application of the regulations on fair value macro hedges when adopted by the European Union. However, hedge accounting under IAS 39 uses the classification and measurement principles of IFRS 9 to decide which financial instruments qualify. Risk management The Investment department of Crédit Agricole Assurances is involved Crédit Agricole Assurances is exposed to a risk arising from an increase in developing and monitoring implementation of the investment policies in interest rates associated with policyholder behaviour: a gap between of Crédit Agricole Assurances Group and of the subsidiaries (taking the rate of return that can be delivered by the insurer (related to bond into account individual ALM limitations and financial objectives), which yields) and the rate expected by policyholders in a high-rate environment, are submitted to their respective Board of Directors for approval. Crédit Agricole Assurances thus implements measures to manage the risk of a rise in rates: 1. Interest rate risk nn adjustment of duration according to projected outflows of liabilities; Type of exposure and risk management nn retention of liquidities or liquid investments with a low risk of loss; Interest rate risk refers to the risk of a change in the value of the bond nn dynamic management of the investment portfolio and setting aside portfolio due to upward or downward movements in interest rates. reserves to provide the capacity to increase the return (capitalisation The Crédit Agricole Assurances Group bond portfolio, excluding unitreserve, and profit-sharing reserves); linked policies, amounted to €269 billion at 31 December 2018, up from nn upward interest rate hedging through derivatives; €249 billion at the end of 2017. nn building customer loyalty to limit early redemptions. Interest rate risk for the life insurance companies is linked to interactions The Crédit Agricole Assurances Group’s dashboard, presented to the between assets (financial management) and liabilities (policyholder Executive Committee and the Audit and Accounts Committee, includes behaviour). Management of this risk requires a global approach combining indicators to monitor the nature of this risk: average guaranteed financial strategy, the constitution of reserves and sales and income minimum rate, bond portfolio coverage ratio, allocation to reserves, etc. policies. Crédit Agricole Assurances’ framework for managing interest rate risk sets out the limits on risks and the related (ALM Committee, Analysis of sensitivity to interest rate risk presentation of stress scenarios to the Board of Directors, etc.). Technical liabilities A low interest rate environment puts pressure on the profitability of the life insurance activities of Crédit Agricole Assurances: it creates The Crédit Agricole Assurances Group’s technical liabilities are largely a situation in which returns from securities in the portfolio are lower insensitive to rate risks for the following reasons: than the rates paid out on life insurance contracts. Risks related to the nn savings provisions (over 90% of technical reserves, excluding unitminimum guaranteed returns in France are handled at regulatory level linked policies): these technical reserves are based on the pricing by means of prudential provisions. rate which is constant over time for a particular policy. As a result, Crédit Agricole Assurances has a range of levers to tackle the risk of a change in interest rates will have no impact on the value of these falling rates: commitments; nn no longer issuing policies that feature guaranteed return (since 2000 nn property and casualty reserves: these technical reserves are not for the main French life insurance company), so that the overall discounted to present value and changes in interest rates therefore average return has steadily fallen; have no impact on the value of these commitments; nn moderation of the profit-sharing paid; nn mathematical reserves for benefits (personal injury, disability): the nn hedging using bond assets and swaps/swaptions to manage discount rate used in calculating these reserves is based on the reinvestment risk; interest rate in force at the calculation date. Therefore, the size of these commitments varies with interest rates. However, given nn adapting of ALM and investment policies to the very low rate the limited amount of these technical commitments, they pose no environment; material risk for Crédit Agricole Assurances Group. nn prudent diversification of investment assets; nn adapting the sales policy in favour of deposits to unit-linked contracts. Group use the advanced measures approach (AMA): Crédit Agricole Corporate and Investment Identification and qualitative assessment Bank, Amundi, LCL, Crédit Agricole Consumer Finance and Agos. These entities Risk mapping is done annually by the entities and is used by each currently represent 72% of capital requirements for operational risks. entity with a validation of the results and associated action plans by the Operational Risk Committee (operational risk unit of the Internal For the entities that use the standardised approach (TSA), the regulatory Control Committee) and a presentation to the Risk Committee of the weighting coefficients used in calculating the capital requirement are Board of Directors. those recommended by the Basel Committee (percentage of revenues according to business line). This mapping is supplemented by the establishment of risk indicators to monitor the most sensitive processes. The calculation and regulatory reporting of capital for The systems implemented within the Group aim for compliance with operational risk at the consolidated and entity levels all qualitative criteria (integration of risk measurement into day-to-day The quarterly production of an operational risk dashboard at management, independence of the Risk function, periodic disclosure entity level, accompanied by a Crédit Agricole Group summary, of operational risk exposures, etc.) and Basel 3 quantitative criteria taking into account the main sources of risks affecting the (99.9% confidence interval over a one-year period; incorporation of business lines and associated action plans for major incidents. internal data, external data, scenario analyses and factors reflecting the operating environment; incorporation of risk factors that influence the statistical distribution, etc.). Management and the business lines; For external factors, the Group uses: nn it must be robust, i.e. it must be able to provide estimates that are nn the ORX Insight external consortium database to monitor incidents realistic and stable from one financial year to the next. recorded in other institutions; An annual committee for back-testing the Advanced Measurement nn the SAS OpRisk and ORX News external public databases for: Approach (AMA) model analyses the model’s sensitivity to changes in –– raising awareness among the entities of the main risks that have the risk profile of the entities. Every year, this committee identifies areas impacted other institutions, where improvements are possible, and draws up corresponding action plans. –– assisting experts in the valuation of the main Group vulnerabilities (key scenarios). The operational risk system and methodology have been subject to external audits by the ECB in 2015, 2016 and 2017. These missions made it possible to note the Group’s progress, but also to complete the prudential approach relating to emerging risks (cyber risk, compliance/ conduct risk). III. NON-COMPLIANCE RISKS Compliance is defined as a set of rules and initiatives aimed at ensuring deployment of all commitments made by the Crédit Agricole Group compliance with all legislative and regulatory provisions under the FOCA remediation plan (see below). As part of the entry into specific to banking and financial activities, professional and ethical force of the European Regulation on the Protection of Personal Data standards and practices, the fundamental principles set out in the (GDPR), the Group Data Protection Officer (DPO) reports directly to Group’s Ethics Charter and the instructions, codes of conduct and the Group Compliance Director and is in charge of managing the DPO procedures internal to Group entities in relation to the areas covered department of Crédit Agricole. by Compliance. These include in particular the fight against money The GCD also leads and supervises the sector. Within the Compliance laundering and terrorist financing, compliance with international function, each Compliance Officer updates a non-compliance risk map, sanctions (embargoes, asset freezes, etc.), prevention of internal and and these are consolidated by the Group Compliance department. The external fraud, the fight against corruption and the exercise of the control of non-compliance risks is more broadly based on a system that right to alert, respect for the integrity of financial markets, customer integrates permanent indicators and controls regularly deployed within protection, tax compliance rules and the protection of personal data. the entities. PILLAR 3 DISCLOSURES Regulation (EU) No. 575/2013 of the European Parliament and of the The internal process ICAAP is developed in accordance with the Council of 26 June 2013 (Capital Requirements Regulation or “CRR”) interpretation of the main regulatory texts specified below (Basel requires relevant financial institutions (notably credit institutions and agreements, guidelines of the European Banking Authority, prudential investment firms) to disclose quantitative and qualitative information expectations of the European Central Bank). In turn, as in previous years, Crédit Agricole S.A. Group and Crédit Agricole Group are subject to additional capital requirements and capital adequacy ratios applying to financial conglomerates. The Maximum Distributable 2.50% Amount (MDA, the maximum sum a bank is allowed to allocate to 1.88% distributions) principle aims to place limitations on distributions in the event the latter were to result in non-compliance with combined buffer 1.50% 1.50% requirements. The trigger threshold for the MDA is expressed as the CET1 capital requirement, plus any potential amounts of AT1 and Tier 2 capital below the minimum regulatory requirement under Pillar 1. 4.50% 4.50% For Crédit Agricole S.A., as of 31 December 2018, the trigger threshold for the MDA was 7.9% of RWA, i.e. CET1 capital in the amount of €24 billion. It should increase to 8.7% as of 1 July 2019 (date on which the French countercyclical buffer enters into force). With a CET1 ratio of 31/12/2018 31/12/2019 11.5% as of 31 December 2018, Crédit Agricole S.A. has a safety margin 360 bps over the trigger threshold for the MDA, i.e. CET1 capital in the amount of €11 billion. Risks and Pillar 3 4. Pillar 3 disclosures 4.1.7. Other ratios 4.1.7.2. Leverage ratio 4.1.7.1. Financial conglomerate ratio Article 429 of the CRR specifying the methods for calculating the leverage ratio was amended and replaced by Delegated Regulation (EU) As at 31 December 2018, Crédit Agricole S.A.’s financial conglomerate 2015/62 of 10 October 2014. The Delegated Regulation was published ratio, which now includes the Solvency 2 requirement relating to the in the Official Journal of the European Union on 18 January 2015. equity interest in Crédit Agricole Assurances, is 179% on a phased-in basis, a level well above the minimum 100% requirement. Publication of the ratio at least once a year is mandatory since 1 January 2015; institutions can choose to publish a fully loaded ratio, The conglomerate ratio is defined as the ratio of the phased-in total a phased-in ratio or both ratios. capital of the financial conglomerate to the cumulative total of the bank’s capital requirements and insurance company’s capital requirements: If the institution decides to change its publication choice, at the time of first publication it must reconcile the data for all of the ratios previously nn it includes all banking and insurance requirements, restating the published with the data for the new ratios selected for publication. share of intragroup transactions related to equity investments from both the numerator and the denominator; An observation period has been introduced for the leverage ratio running from 1 January 2014 to 1 January 2017 to monitor the components and nn the insurance subsidiary’s capital raised outside of the scope of the behaviour of the ratio relative to the requirements based on risks. consolidation is included in the conglomerate’s capital. At this stage, the implementation of Pillar 1 (minimum regulatory Total capital requirement), initially planned for 1 January 2018, has been delayed, Financial of the conglomerate and will take place as part of the CRR2 transposition. = > 100% conglomerate ratio Banking Insurance + A requirement for a two-level leverage ratio is provided for in CRR 2: requirements requirements it will be 3% for non G-SIBs and 3% plus half of the entity’s systemic buffer for G-SIBs. The “conglomerate” view is the most relevant for a bancassurance group. The conglomerate combines banks and insurance companies, The leverage ratio is defined as the Tier 1 capital divided by the exposure which corresponds to the natural scope of the Group. Moreover, the measure, i.e. balance sheet and off-balance-sheet assets after certain conglomerate ratio reflects the actual risks borne by each of the two restatements of derivatives, transactions between Group affiliates, activities. Therefore, the conglomerate ratio view is economic, whereas securities financing transactions, items deducted from the numerator, the bank solvency ratio treats insurance as an equity investment. and off-balance-sheet items. At 31 December 2018, Crédit Agricole S.A.’s leverage ratio stood at 4.0%(1) on a phased-in Tier 1 basis: the ratio is down compared to 4.4% at end 2017 (including the non-weighting of intragroup operations). This decrease is mainly due to the organic growth, while the Total capital is stable following the entry in force of IFRS 9. The intra-quarter phased-in leverage ratio for Crédit Agricole S.A., which refers to the average end-of-month exposures for the first two months of the fourth quarter, amounted to 3.7%. 5 (1) The leverage ratio amounts to 4.2% subject to the issue by the ECB of an authorisation to exempt exposures linked to the centralisation of deposits with the Caisse des dépôts et consignations to take account of Judgement T-758/16 of the General Court of the European Union of 13 July 2018. securitisations, and other non-credit obligation assets) 74,425 The qualitative elements (LRQua) required by Implementing Regulation More generally, the BRRD establishes a framework for the resolution 5 (EU) 2016/200 of 15 February 2016 are as follows: of banks throughout the European Union and with the aim of equipping resolution authorities with shared instruments and powers to Description of the procedures used to manage the risk pre-emptively tackle banking crises, preserve financial stability and of excessive leverage reduce taxpayers’ exposure to losses. The leverage ratio is not sensitive to risk factors and, on this basis, The MREL ratio corresponds to the minimum requirement of own funds it is considered to be a measurement that supplements the solvency and eligible liabilities that must be available to absorb losses in the (solvency ratio/resolution ratio) and liquidity risk management system event of resolution. This minimum requirement is calculated as being the already limiting the size of the balance sheet. Within the framework amount of own funds and eligible liabilities expressed as a percentage of monitoring excessive leverage, controls at Group level set limits on of the institution’s total liabilities and capital, after certain regulatory the size of the balance sheet for some businesses that use few riskadjustments. In this calculation, total liabilities takes into account the full weighted assets. recognition of netting rights applicable to derivatives. Resolution ratios The MREL ratio calibrates an eligible liabilities requirement but does MREL ratio not specify which debt would be called upon to absorb losses in the event of resolution. The MREL (Minimum Requirement for Own Funds and Eligible Liabilities) ratio, is defined in the European “Bank Recovery and Resolution Directive” (BRRD), published on 12 June 2014 and effective since 1 January 2015 (except for provisions on bail-in and MREL, which are applicable since 1 January 2016). Overall system The Group has implemented an economic capital requirement measuring system covering Crédit Agricole Group, Crédit Agricole S.A. Group and In order to assess and permanently maintain adequate capital to cover the Group’s main French and foreign entities. the risks to which it is (or may be) exposed, the Group supplements the measurement of regulatory capital requirements (Pillar 1) with 4.2.2. Available internal capital measurement of economic capital requirement based on the risk identification process and on a valuation using an internal approach The Group has also defined the available internal capital (an internal (Pillar 2). view of capital), which is compared to the economic capital requirement. The assessment of economic capital requirement is one of the ICAAP Internal capital is defined as part of a conglomerate approach – (Internal Capital Adequacy Assessment Process) components, which considering the importance of the Group’s insurance businesses, and also covers: is based on consideration of the TLAC constraints and of the going nn the stress test programme – in order to introduce a forward-looking concern principle. view for the impact less favourable scenarios would have on the risk level and the Group’s solvency; and 4.2.3. Economic capital requirement nn capital requirement management within the Group through capital The economic capital requirement quantifies capital requirements planning, capital allocation, and profitability management. for each of the major risks identified in the annual risk identification Each sub-group is responsible for ICAAP implementation and updating. process. Economic capital management is developed in accordance with the The major risk identification process initially aims to list as exhaustively interpretation of the main regulatory texts: as possible all the risks that are likely to impact the Group’s balance nn the Basel agreement; sheet, income statement, solvency ratios, or the reputation of an entity or the Group and to apply a Group-wide, standard approach to placing nn CRD 4 through its transposition into French regulations by the Decree them in categories and sub-categories. At 31 December 2018, total exposure for the scope defined above was €1,283.9 billion (of which €314.4 billion in Crédit Agricole S.A. Group internal transactions), compared with €1,193.8 billion at 31 December 2017. For all supervisory approaches (i.e. based on internal and standard ratings), concerning Retail customers, the Group’s exposure is concentrated on two countries: France and Italy represent 85% of exposures. The other portfolios are more geographically diversified. For example, close to 30% of exposures in the Corporate portfolio are located outside Europe, primarily in North America and Asia. 290 CRÉDIT AGRICOLE S.A. | 2018 Registration Document The definitions of the underlined words can be found in the Glossary on page 600. Conversely, the share of “revolving retail loans” fell further in 2018 to 7.7% of outstanding retail customer loans from 8.4% in 2017. The increase in the stock of provisions / impairment is mainly due to the increase in healthy loans which, according to IFRS 9, are provisioned from the onset. CRÉDIT AGRICOLE S.A. | 2018 Registration Document 299 5 Risks and Pillar 3 4. Pillar 3 disclosures The information on non-performing and renegotiated exposures includes the gross carrying amount, impairment, provisions and related valuation adjustments, as well as the value of collateral and guarantees received. The definitions of defaulted, impaired, renegotiated or restructured exposures are given in the financial statements in Part 1.2 “Accounting principles and methods”. Back-testing results Periodic inspection is conducted annually by the Internal Audit function In the following paragraphs, back-testing covers all the methods and or any third party specifically authorised by it. The audit plan covers: procedures used to verify the performance and stability of the internal nn systems for calculating ratings and estimating risk parameters, as risk models (PD, LGD, CCF), specifically by comparing forecasts with well as compliance with minimum requirements; actual results. nn systems functioning (correct implementation). With regard to permanent control, a back-testing Committee has been The corresponding reports are sent to the person responsible for established within each entity. The Committee (which may, for some monitoring the relevant entity within the Group Risk Management entities, be a specific agenda item for the Risk Committee) is chaired department. by the Risk Management department of the relevant entity and includes The entity performs internal controls (permanent and periodic) on: a representative from the Group Risk Management and Permanent nn the quality of input and output data within the system; Controls department. It meets at least twice a year and is the subject nn the conceptual and technical quality of systems for calculating ratings of reports to the Chief Executive Officer and the Head of the entity’s Permanent Control department, as well as the Group Risk Management and estimating risk parameters; department. nn the completeness of data used for the calculation of risk-weighted assets. 316 CRÉDIT AGRICOLE S.A. | 2018 Registration Document The definitions of the underlined words can be found in the Glossary on page 600. Risks and Pillar 3 4. Pillar 3 disclosures Back-testing is critical in maintaining the pertinence and performance Management department or its delegate). This provides the Group of rating models. A first phase of analysis is based chiefly on the annually, through the Standards and Methodologies Committee, with the quantitative analysis of the predictive model as a whole and its main result of back-testing after consulting an ad hoc Committee to confirm explanatory variables. the proper application of selected statistical methods and the validity of This exercise can also detect significant changes in the structure results, and proposes, where appropriate, suitable corrective measures and behaviour of portfolios and customers. Back-testing then results (revision of the method, recalibration, training, recommendations for in decisions to adjust or recast models in order to factor in the new control, etc.). structural elements. This allows changes in non-cyclical behaviour These ex-post controls are performed – through the cycle – on historical or change in the franchise to be identified, revealing the impact of data covering as long a period as possible. CVA Under the directive, banks use a regulatory formula (“standardised The CRD 4 directive brought in a new capital charge to cover volatility approach”) or are authorised to calculate their capital requirements in the CVA (Credit Valuation Adjustment) or valuation adjustment for using their internal models for both counterparty risk and specific rate assets grouped together under the term “CVA Risk”, which is intended risk using the advanced method (“CVA VaR”). to include in the valuation of OTC derivatives credit events affecting The CVA requirement under the advanced approach is calculated on our counterparties. The CVA is thus defined as the difference between the basis of expected positive exposure on OTC derivative transactions the valuation excluding risk of default and the valuation including the involving “Financial institution” counterparties excluding intragroup probability of default of our counterparties. transactions. Within this scope, the tools used to estimate capital requirements are the same as for market VaR in respect of specific interest rate risk. Risks and Pillar 3 4. Pillar 3 disclosures 4.4.2.4. Credit and counterparty risk mitigation techniques Definitions: nn collateral: a security interest giving the bank the right to liquidate, keep or obtain title to certain amounts or assets in the event of default or other specific credit events affecting the counterparty, thereby reducing the credit risk on an exposure; nn personal guarantee: undertaking by a third party to pay a sum in the event of the counterparty’s default or other specific credit events, therefore reducing the credit risks on an exposure. Derivative exposures Cash outflows for this item mainly materialise the risk associated with increases in margin calls and potential collateral calls on derivative transactions in an unfavourable market scenario and increases in margin calls following a deterioration in the Group’s external rating. At 31 December 2018, the total collateral the Group would need to provide in case of downgrading of its credit rating amounted to €3.3 billion. Currency mismatch in the LCR At 31 December 2018, Crédit Agricole S.A. Group had its net cash outflows covered by liquid assets denominated in the same currency in the main material currencies. The extent of residual mismatches observed in certain currencies is considered satisfactory, given the surplus top quality liquid assets available in the other material currencies, which could easily be converted to cover the requirements, including in a crisis situation. A description of the degree Crédit Agricole S.A. controls the management of liquidity risk. of centralisation of liquidity • Crédit Agricole S.A.’s cash enables it to meet the main short term refinancing needs (≤ 1 year) of the management and interaction between Regional Banks and the subsidiaries. It also coordinates the cash position of the subsidiaries for their the Group’s units additional fundraising. CACIB operates self-sufficiently for the management of its short-term refinancing, in close coordination with Crédit Agricole’s Cash Management department; 5 • for long-term refinancing (> 1 year), Crédit Agricole S.A. collects the long-term resource needs, plans refinancing programmes according to these needs and reallocates resources raised to Group entities. The Group’s main issuers are: Crédit Agricole S.A., CACIB, CA-CF, and CA Italia. CRÉDIT AGRICOLE S.A. | 2018 Registration Document 359 6 Consolidated Financial Statements Consolidated financial statements CASH FLOW STATEMENT The cash flow statement is presented using the indirect method. Financing activities show the impact of cash inflows and outflows Operating activities are representative of income-generating associated with operations of financial structure concerning equity and activities of the Crédit Agricole S.A. Group. long-term borrowing. Tax inflows and outflows are included in full within operating activities. The net cash flows attributable to the operating, investment and financing activities of discontinued operations are presented on Investment activities show the impact of cash inflows and outflows separate lines in the cash flow statement. associated with purchases and sales of investments in consolidated and non-consolidated companies, property, plant and equipment and Net cash and cash equivalents include cash, debit and credit intangible assets. This section includes strategic equity investments balances with central banks and debit and credit demand balances classified as at “Fair value through profit or loss” or “Fair value through with credit institutions. other comprehensive income on items that cannot be reclassified”. 360 CRÉDIT AGRICOLE S.A. | 2018 Registration Document The definitions of the underlined words can be found in the Glossary on page 600.
