million and from Crédit Agricole Immobilier for €5 million. (2) Change in equity investments: this line shows the net effects on cash of acquisitions and disposals of equity investments. The net impact on Group cash of acquisitions and disposals of consolidated equity investments (subsidiaries and equity-accounted entities) on 31 December 2018 is -€410 million. The main transactions relate to the acquisition of Banca Leonardo for -€20 million net of cash of acquired, the inclusion into the scope of consolidation of Iris Holding for -€88 million, the sale of Caceis USA and Caceis Canada for +€14 million, the sale of Banque Thémis for -€40 million, the subscription to the capital increases of equity-accounted entities with Frey for -€44 million, Amundi entities for -€69 million and CACF entities for -€89 million. During the same period, the net impact on Group cash of acquisitions and disposals of non-consolidated equity investments came to -€656 million, of which -€756 million from insurance investments. (3) Cash received from (paid to) shareholders: the main operation relates to the increase of capital reserved to employees for €135 million. This amount is predominantly comprised of -€2,611 million in dividends paid, excluding dividends paid in shares, by Crédit Agricole S.A. Group. It breaks down as follows: dividends paid by Crédit Agricole S.A. for -€1,802 million; dividends paid by non-controlled subsidiaries for -€366 million; and interest, equivalent to dividends on undated financial instruments treated as equity for -€443 million. (4) Other net cash flows from financing activities: at 31 December 2018, bond issues totalled €15,314 million and redemptions -€8,783 million. Subordinated debt issues totalled €2,624 million and redemptions -€5,430 million. This line also includes cash flows from interest payments on subordinated debt and bonds for -€3,190 million. Classification and measurement of financial assets Non-derivative financial assets (debt or equity instruments) are Financial instruments (IFRS 9, IAS 39 and IAS 32) classified on the balance sheet in accounting categories that determine their accounting treatment and their subsequent valuation mode. These Definitions financial assets are classified in one of the following three categories: IAS 32 defines a financial instrument as any contract that gives rise to a nn financial assets at fair value through profit or loss; financial asset of one entity and a financial liability or equity instrument nn financial assets at amortised cost; of another entity, meaning any contract representing contractual rights nn financial assets at fair value through other comprehensive income. or obligations to receive or pay cash or other financial assets. The criteria for the classification and valuation of financial assets Derivative instruments are financial assets or liabilities whose value depends on the nature of the financial assets, according to whether changes according to that of an underlying asset, which requires a low they are qualified as: or nil initial investment, and for which settlement occurs at a future date. nn debt instruments (i.e. loans and fixed or determinable income Financial assets and liabilities are treated in the financial statements in securities); or accordance with IFRS 9 as adopted by the European Union, including for nn equity instruments (i.e. shares). financial assets held by the Group’s insurance entities. Debt instruments IFRS 9 sets the principles governing the classification and measurement of financial instruments, impairment of credit risk and hedging The classification and valuation of a debt instrument depends on the accounting, excluding macro-hedging transactions. combination of two criteria: the business model and the analysis of the contractual terms, unless the fair value option is used. It should nevertheless be noted that the Crédit Agricole S.A. Group nn The three business models: has opted not to apply the IFRS 9 general hedging model. All hedging relationships consequently remain within the scope of IAS 39 pending The business model represents the strategy followed by the future provisions relating to macro-hedging. management of the Crédit Agricole S.A. Group for managing its financial assets in order to achieve its objectives. The business Conventions for valuing financial assets and liabilities model is specified for a portfolio of assets and does not constitute a case-by-case intention for an isolated financial asset. Initial valuation We distinguish three business models: During their initial recognition, financial assets and liabilities are measured at fair value as defined by IFRS 13. –– the collection only model for which the aim is to collect contractual cash flows over the lifetime of the assets; this model does not Fair value as defined by IFRS 13 corresponds to the price that would always imply holding all of the assets until their contractual be received to sell an asset or paid to transfer a liability in an ordinary maturity; however, sales of assets are strictly governed, transaction between market participants, on the principal or the most –– the mixed model where the aim is to collect the contractual cash advantageous market, at the measurement date. flows over the lifetime of the assets and to sell the assets; under Subsequent valuation this model, both the sale of the financial assets and receipt of cash After initial recognition, financial assets and liabilities are measured flows are essential, and according to their classification either at amortised cost using the –– the selling only model, where the main aim is to sell the assets. effective interest rate method (EIR) or at fair value as defined by IFRS 13. In particular, it concerns portfolios where the aim is to collect cash For derivative instruments, they are always measured at their fair value. flows via sales, portfolios whose performance is assessed based Amortised cost corresponds to the amount at which the financial on fair value and portfolios of financial assets held for trading. asset or liability is measured during its initial recognition, including nn The contractual terms (“Solely Payments of Principal & Interest” transaction costs directly attributable to its acquisition or issue, reduced [SPPI] test): by repayments of principal, increased or reduced by the cumulative –– SPPI testing combines a set of criteria, examined cumulatively, to amortisation calculated by the effective interest rate method (EIR) on establish whether contractual cash flows meet the characteristics any difference (discount or premium) between the initial amount and of simple financing (principal repayments and interest payments the amount at maturity. In the case of a financial asset, the amount is on the remaining amount of principal due); adjusted if necessary in order to correct for impairment (see the section –– the test is satisfied when the financing gives entitlement only to on “Provisions for credit risk”). the repayment of the principal and when the payment of interest The effective interest rate (EIR) is the rate that exactly discounts received reflects the time value of money, the credit risk associated estimated future cash payments or receipts through the expected life with the instrument, the other costs and risks of a conventional of the financial instrument or, when appropriate, a shorter period, to loan contract and a reasonable margin, whether the interest rate obtain the net carrying amount of the financial asset or financial liability. is fixed or variable. In simple financing, interest represents the cost of the passage of time, the price of credit and liquidity risk over the period, and other components related to the cost of carrying the asset (e.g. administrative costs). In some cases, when qualitative analysis of this nature does not allow a conclusion to be made, quantitative analysis (or benchmark testing) is carried out. This additional analysis consists of comparing the contractual cash flows of the asset under review with the cash flows of a benchmark asset. 374 CRÉDIT AGRICOLE S.A. | 2018 Registration Document The definitions of the underlined words can be found in the Glossary on page 600. Definition of expected credit loss (“ECL”) The process of provisioning credit risk has three stages (Buckets): ECL is defined as the weighted expected probable value of the nn Bucket 1: upon initial recognition of the financial instrument (credit, discounted credit loss (principal and interest). It represents the present debt security, guarantee, etc.), the entity recognises the 12-month value of the difference between the contractual cash flows and the expected credit losses; expected cash flows (including principal and interest). CRÉDIT AGRICOLE S.A. | 2018 Registration Document 387 6 Consolidated Financial Statements Notes to the consolidated financial statements Note 1 1.3 CONSOLIDATION PRINCIPLES AND METHODS (IFRS 10, IFRS 11 AND IAS 28) Scope of consolidation Joint control is deemed to exist when there is a contractual division of control over an economic activity. Decisions affecting the entity’s The consolidated financial statements include the financial statements relevant activities require unanimous agreement of the joint controllers. of Crédit Agricole S.A. and those of all companies over which, in compliance with IFRS 10, IFRS 11 and IAS 28, Crédit Agricole S.A. In traditional entities, significant influence is defined as the power to exercises control, joint control or significant influence. influence but not control a company’s financial and operational policies. Crédit Agricole S.A. is presumed to have significant influence if it owns 20% or more of the voting rights in an entity, whether directly or Definitions of control indirectly through subsidiaries. In compliance with international accounting standards, all entities under control, under joint control or under significant influence are Exclusions from the scope of consolidation consolidated, provided that they are not covered by the exclusions below. In accordance with IAS 28, minority interests held by entities for which the paragraph 18 option has been applied, are excluded from the scope Exclusive control over an entity is deemed to exist if Crédit Agricole of consolidation insofar as they are classified under financial assets at S.A. is exposed to or entitled to receive variable returns as a result of its fair value through profit or loss by nature. involvement with the entity and if the power it holds over this entity allows it to influence these returns. Power in this context means substantive (voting or contractual) rights. Rights are considered substantive if the Consolidation methods holder of the rights can in practice exercise them when decisions about The methods of consolidation are respectively defined by IFRS 10 and the Company’s relevant activities are made. IAS 28 (revised). They depend on the type of control exercised by Crédit Crédit Agricole S.A. is deemed to control a subsidiary through voting Agricole S.A. over the entities that can be consolidated, regardless of rights when its rights give it the practical ability to direct the subsidiary’s activity or whether or not they have legal entity status: relevant activities. Crédit Agricole S.A. is generally considered to control nn full consolidation, for controlled entities, including entities with a subsidiary when it holds more than half the existing or potential voting different financial statement structures, even if their business is not rights in an entity, whether directly or indirectly through subsidiaries, an extension of that of Crédit Agricole S.A.; except when it can be clearly demonstrated that such ownership does nn the equity method, for the entities over which Crédit Agricole S.A. not give it the power to direct its relevant activities. Control is also exercises significant influence and joint control. deemed to exist where Crédit Agricole S.A. holds half or less than half Full consolidation consists in substituting for the value of the shares of the voting rights, including potential rights, in an entity but is able each of the assets and liabilities carried by each subsidiary. The equity in practice to direct its relevant activities at its sole discretion, notably and income attributable to non-controlling interests is presented because of the existence of contractual arrangements, the size of its separately in the consolidated balance sheet and income statement. stake in the voting rights compared to those of other investors, or other reasons. Non-controlling interests are as defined by IFRS 10 and incorporate instruments representing present ownership interests and that give right Control of a structured entity is not assessed on the basis of voting to a proportional share of the net assets in the event of liquidation and rights as these have no effect on the entity’s returns. When assessing the other equity instruments issued by the subsidiary and not held by control, consideration is given not only to contractual arrangements in the Group. force but also to whether Crédit Agricole S.A. was involved in creating the entity and what decisions it made at that time, what agreements The equity method consists in substituting for the value of shares the were made at its inception and what risks are borne by Crédit Agricole Group’s proportional share of the equity and income of the companies S.A., any rights under agreements that give the investor the power to concerned. direct relevant activities in specific circumstances only and any other The change in the carrying amount of these shares includes changes facts or circumstances that indicate the investor can direct the entity’s in goodwill. relevant activities. The tables below show the maximum exposures as well as the amount of collateral held and other credit enhancements allowing this exposure to be reduced. Impaired assets at the end of the reporting period constitute the impaired assets (Bucket 3). Group. 3.1.3 Concentrations of credit risk The carrying amounts and commitments are presented net of impairment and provisions. Exposure to credit risk by category of credit risk The credit risk categories are presented by probability of default intervals. The correspondence between internal ratings and probability of default intervals is discussed in the Chapter entitled “Risk Factors and Pillar 3 – Credit Risk Management” in the Crédit Agricole S.A. CRÉDIT AGRICOLE S.A. | 2018 Registration Document 417 6 Consolidated Financial Statements Notes to the consolidated financial statements Note 3 3.4 CASH FLOW AND FAIR VALUE Future cash flow hedges INTEREST RATE AND FOREIGN A cash flow hedge modifies the risk related to variability in cash flows EXCHANGE HEDGING arising from floating-rate financial instruments. (See Note 3.2 “Market risk” and chapter on “Risk management – Asset/ Items hedged are principally floating-rate loans and deposits. Liability Management”) Hedge of net investment in foreign currency Fair value hedges A hedge of a net investment in foreign currency modifies the risk A fair value hedge modifies the risk caused by changes in the fair value inherent in exchange rate fluctuations connected with foreign currency of a fixed-rate financial instrument as a result of changes in interest investments in subsidiaries. rates. Fair value hedges transform fixed-rate assets or liabilities into floating-rate assets or liabilities. Items hedged are principally fixed-rate loans, securities, deposits and subordinated debts. CRÉDIT AGRICOLE S.A. | 2018 Registration Document 421 6 Consolidated Financial Statements Notes to the consolidated financial statements Note 4 3.5 OPERATIONAL RISKS Information on capital management and compliance with regulatory ratios as required by IAS 1 is presented in the (See chapter on “Risk management – Operational risks”) Chapter “Risks and Pillar 3”. The Group’s management of banking risks is handled by the Group Risk 3.6 CAPITAL MANAGEMENT AND Management and Permanent Controls department. This department REGULATORY RATIOS reports to the Chief Executive Officer of Crédit Agricole S.A. and its task is to control credit, financial and operational risks. Crédit Agricole S.A. Finance department is tasked with ensuring the A description of these processes and commentary appear in the chapter adequacy of liquidity and capital between the requirements generated on “Risk management” in the management report, as allowed by IFRS 7 by the Group’s global operations and its liquidity and capital financial standard. Nonetheless, the accounting breakdowns are still presented resources. It is responsible for monitoring the prudential and regulatory in the financial statements. ratios (solvency, liquidity, leverage, resolution) of Crédit Agricole Group and of Crédit Agricole S.A. To this end, it sets out the principles and ensures a cohesive financial management system throughout the Group. Consolidated Financial Statements Notes to the consolidated financial statements Note 5 6. Corporate Centre nn the results from management companies, real-estate companies This segment mainly encompasses Crédit Agricole S.A.’s central body holding properties used in operations by several business lines and function, asset and liability management and management of debt by activities undergoing reorganisation; connected with acquisitions of subsidiaries or equity investments. nn the net impact of tax consolidation for Crédit Agricole S.A. as well as the revaluation of structured debt issued by Crédit Agricole CIB. It also includes: nn the results of the private equity business and results of various other Crédit Agricole S.A. Group companies (Uni-médias, Foncaris, etc.); 5.1 OPERATING SEGMENT INFORMATION Transactions between operating segments are effected at arm’s length. Calculation of realised gains/losses on own credit risk (recognised Basis for calculating own credit risk in consolidated reserves) The source taken into account for the calculation of own credit risk may The Group has elected to transfer fair value changes attributable to vary from one issuer to another. Within Crédit Agricole S.A.’s Group, the changes in own credit risk upon unwinding to consolidated reserves. source used is the change in its cost of market refinancing. Accordingly, when there is a total or partial early redemption, a sensitivity-based calculation is done. This consists of measuring the Calculation of unrealised gains/losses on own credit adjustment change in fair value attributable to the changes in own credit risk of (recognised in other comprehensive income) a given issuance as being the sum of the credit spread sensitivities The Crédit Agricole’s Group preferred approach is based on the liquidity multiplied by the change in this spread between the issuance date and component of issues. Securitisations Crédit Agricole Consumer Finance Securitisations Consolidated securitisations with external investors are a transfer of At 31 December 2018, Crédit Agricole Consumer Finance managed 16 assets within the meaning of the amendment to IFRS 7. The Group consolidated vehicles for securitisation of retail consumer loans and car effectively has an indirect contractual obligation to deliver to external dealer financing in Europe. Securitisation transactions carried out within investors the cash flows from assets sold to the securitisation fund Crédit Agricole Consumer Finance Group are not considered to form part (although these assets are recorded in the Group balance sheet through of a deconsolidation transaction under IFRS and have therefore been the consolidation of the fund). Receivables assigned to the securitisation reintegrated into Crédit Agricole S.A. Group’s consolidated financial fund are used as collateral for investors. statements. Fully self-subscribed consolidated securitisations do not constitute a transfer of assets within the meaning of IFRS 7. 448 CRÉDIT AGRICOLE S.A. | 2018 Registration Document The definitions of the underlined words can be found in the Glossary on page 600. Significant restrictions on joint ventures and associates Crédit Agricole S.A. Group has the following restrictions: These requirements limit the ability of the subsidiaries to distribute dividends. In the majority of cases, these are less restrictive than the Regulatory constraints regulatory limitations mentioned above. The subsidiaries of Crédit Agricole S.A. Group are subject to prudential regulation and regulatory capital requirements in their host countries. Restriction on assets backing unit-linked contracts for the The minimum equity capital (solvency ratio), leverage ratio and liquidity Insurance business ratio requirements limit the capacity of these entities to pay dividends Assets backing unit-linked contracts of Crédit Agricole S.A. Group or to transfer assets to Crédit Agricole S.A. Group. are held for the benefit of policyholders. Assets of the insurance subsidiaries of Crédit Agricole S.A. Group are mainly held for satisfying Legal constraints their obligation towards their policyholders. Assets transfers to other The subsidiaries of Crédit Agricole S.A. Group are subject to legal entities are possible following the legal conditions. However, in case of provisions concerning the distribution of capital and distributable earnings. a transfer, a part of the profit due to the transfer must be intended for the policyholders. 6.13 INVESTMENT PROPERTIES Changes Increases Decreases Translation Other (in millions of euros) 31/12/2017 01/01/2018 in scope (acquisitions) (disposals) adjustments movements 31/12/2018 Gross amount 6,283 6,283 153 518 (558) 96 6,492 Amortisation and impairment (87) (87) (3) 18 (12) (84) CARRYING AMOUNT(1) 6,196 6,196 153 515 (540) 84 6,408 (1) Including investment property let to third parties. Securities bought or sold under participants at the measurement date. repurchase agreements with underlyings quoted in an active market Fair value is defined on the basis of the exit price. are also included in Level 2 of the hierarchy, as are financial assets and liabilities with a demand component for which fair value is measured at The fair values shown below are estimates made on the reporting date unadjusted amortised cost. using observable market data wherever possible. These are subject to change in subsequent periods due to developments in market conditions Level 3 indicates the fair value of financial assets and liabilities with or other factors. unobservable inputs or for which some data can be revalued using internal models based on historical data. This mainly includes market The calculations represent best estimates. They are based on a number data relating to credit risk or early redemption risk. of assumptions. It is assumed that market participants act in their best economic interest. In some cases, market values are close to carrying amounts. This applies primarily to: To the extent that these models contain uncertainties, the fair values nn assets or liabilities at variable rates for which interest rate changes shown may not be achieved upon actual sale or immediate settlement of the financial instruments concerned. do not have a significant influence on the fair value, since the rates on these instruments frequently adjust themselves to the market rates; The fair value hierarchy of financial assets and liabilities is broken down nn short-term assets or liabilities where the redemption value is according to the general observability criteria of the valuation inputs, considered to be close to the market value; pursuant to the principles defined under IFRS 13. nn instruments executed on a regulated market for which the prices are Level 1 applies to the fair value of financial assets and liabilities quoted set by the public authorities; in active markets. nn demand assets and liabilities; Level 2 applies to the fair value of financial assets and liabilities with nn transactions for which there are no reliable observable data. observable inputs. The value adjustment linked to the counterparts quality (CVA) aims to nn models approved by the quantitative teams in the Market Risk incorporate in derivatives’ valuation the credit risk associated with the department. counterparty (risk of non-payment of sums due in the event of default). The valuation produced for each instrument is a mid-market valuation, This adjustment is calculated on an aggregate basis by counterparty which does not take account of the direction of the trade, the according to the future exposure profile of the transactions after bank’s aggregate exposure, market liquidity or counterparty quality. deducting any collateral. This adjustment is always negative and Adjustments are then made to the market valuations to incorporate reduces the fair value of the financial instruments. those factors, as well as the potential uncertainties inherent in the The value adjustment linked to our institution’s own credit risk (Debt models or inputs used. Value Adjustment – DVA) aims to incorporate the risk borne by our The main types of valuation adjustments are the following: counterparties in the valuation of derivative instruments. This adjustment nn Mark-to-Market adjustments: these adjustments correct any is calculated on an aggregate basis by counterparty according to the potential variance between the mid-market valuation of an instrument future exposure profile of the transactions. This adjustment is always obtained using internal valuation models and the associated inputs positive and reduces the fair value of the financial instruments. and the valuation obtained from external sources or market consensus The CVA/DVA is calculated on the basis of estimated expected data. This The Funding Valuation Adjustment (FVA) is a mark-to-market adjustment is always negative and reduces the fair value of the OTC adjustment that aims to incorporate in the fair value of OTC derivatives derivative assets held in the portfolio. the additional future funding costs and benefits based on ALM (Asset & Liability Management) funding costs. This adjustment is calculated on the scope of transactions that are not covered by a CSA (Credit Support Annex) or covered by a non-perfect CSA/Golden and on the basis of future exposition profiles (positive and negative) weighted by the ALM funding spreads. As regards the scope of “clear” derivatives, an FVA adjustment called IMVA (Initial Margin Value Adjustment) is calculated to take into account the future financing costs and gains of the initial margins to be posted with the main derivatives clearing houses until the portfolio matures. 6 The definitions of the underlined words can be found in the Glossary on page 600. Financial instruments classified in Level 1 Financial instruments classified in Level 2 Level 1 comprises all derivatives quoted in an active market (options, The main financial instruments classified in Level 2 are: futures, etc.), regardless of their underlying (interest rate, exchange rate, precious metals, key stock indices), as well as equities and bonds Liabilities designated at fair value through profit or loss quoted in an active market. Financial liabilities designated at fair value are classified in Level 2 when their embedded derivative is deemed to be classified in Level 2. A market is considered as being active if quoted prices are readily and regularly available from exchange, brokers, dealers, pricing services or Over-the-counter derivatives regulatory agencies, and those prices represent actual and regularly The main OTC derivatives classified in Level 2 are those valued using occurring market transactions on an arm’s length basis. inputs considered to be observable and where the valuation technique Corporate, government and agency bonds that are valued on the basis does not generate any significant exposure to a model risk. of prices obtained from independent sources, deemed to be enforceable Level 2 therefore mainly includes: and updated regularly, are classified in Level 1. This covers the bulk of nn linear derivative products such as interest rate swaps, currency sovereign, agency and corporate securities held. Issuers whose bonds are not quoted are classified in Level 3. swaps and forward FX. They are valued using simple models widely used in the market, based either on directly observable inputs (foreign exchange rates, interest rates), or inputs derived from observable market prices (currency swaps); nn non-linear vanilla instruments such as caps, floors, swaptions, 6 currency options, equity options and credit default swaps, including digital options. They are valued using simple models widely used in the market, based either on directly observable inputs (foreign exchange rates, interest rates, share prices) or inputs that can be derived from observable market prices (volatilities); The definitions of the underlined words can be found in the Glossary on page 600. Consolidated Financial Statements Notes to the consolidated financial statements Note 11 With respect to the prepayment rate The pre-payment rate is not an observable market parameter and Direct exposure to assets comprising a pre-payment risk concerns the valuation model used for the securitisation swaps is particularly securitisations such as RMBS and CLO and mezzanine CDO tranches. conservative. The valuation used is defined as the lower of the valuation These exposures are marginal. They can be taken into account through obtained using a very fast pre-payment rate and using a very slow sensitivity to a 1 bp change in credit spreads. This sensitivity being pre-payment rate. A “normal” variation in the pre-payment rate will very low (<€50 thousand/bp), exposure to pre-payment rate is thus therefore have no material impact on mark-to-market, no Day One thus considered to be negligible. being used for these products. 10.3 ESTIMATED IMPACT OF INCLUSION OF THE MARGIN AT INCEPTION The 1st day margin on market transactions falling within Level 3 of fair (in millions of euros) 31/12/2018 31/12/2017 value is reserved for the balance sheet and recognised in profit or loss Deferred margin at 1 January 67 69 as time passes or when unobservable parameters become observable Margin generated by new transactions again. during the period 26 20 Recognised in net income during the period Amortisation and cancelled/reimbursed/ matured transactions (32) (22) Profit-sharing and incentive plans Effects of inputs or products reclassified as observable during the period DEFERRED MARGIN AT THE END OF THE PERIOD 61 67 Note 11 Scope of consolidation at 31 December 2018 11.1 INFORMATION ON SUBSIDIARIES The payment of CA Egypt dividends is subject to a currency translation restriction on the Egyptian pound imposed by the Banque Centrale d’Égypte. 11.1.1 Restrictions on entities Crédit Agricole S.A. Consolidated Financial Statements Notes to the consolidated financial statements Note 12 Note 12 Investments in non-consolidated companies and structured entities 12.1 INFORMATION ON SUBSIDIARIES 12.1.2 Material non-consolidated equity investments This line item amounted to €12,170 million at 31 December 2018, compared Material equity investments accounting for a fraction of capital greater with €12,277 million at 31 December 2017. At 31 December 2018, the than or equal to 10% and not included in the scope of consolidation are main investment in non-consolidated companies where percentage presented in a table available online on the Crédit Agricole S.A. website of control is greater than 20% and which have significant value on at the time of publication of the Registration Document. the balance sheet is Crédit Logement (shares A and B). The Group’s investment represents 32.49% of Crédit Logement’s capital and amounts to €522 million but does not confer any significant influence over this entity, which is jointly held by various French banks and companies. 12.1.1 Non-consolidated controlled entities Information relating to conventional entities under exclusive control, under joint control and subject to significant influence, and to controlled structured entities not included in the scope of consolidation are available on the Crédit Agricole S.A. Group website at the time of publication of the Registration Document. 12.2 NON-CONSOLIDATED STRUCTURED ENTITIES IFRS 12 defines a structured entity as an entity that has been designed Their value and returns are correlated to these commitments. so that voting or similar rights are not the dominant factor in deciding who controls the entity, such as when any voting rights relate to the Structured finance administrative tasks only and the relevant activities are directed by Lastly, Crédit Agricole S.A. Group, via its subsidiaries in the Large means of contractual arrangements. customers business line, is involved in special purpose asset acquisition entities. These entities may take the form of asset financing companies Information on the nature and extent of interests or lease financing companies. These are investment funds in which the Group is not a manager, and structured financing entities in which the Group has only granted a loan. Maximum exposure to loss risk The maximum exposure to loss risk on financial instruments corresponds to the value recognised on the balance sheet, with the exception of option sale derivatives and credit default swaps for which the exposure corresponds to assets for the notional amount and to liabilities for the notional amount less the mark-to-market. The maximum exposure to loss risk on commitments given corresponds to the notional amount and the provision for commitments given in the amount recognised on the balance sheet. Note 13 Events subsequent to 31 December 2018 No significant events took place after the balance sheet date. 510 CRÉDIT AGRICOLE S.A. | 2018 Registration Document The definitions of the underlined words can be found in the Glossary on page 600. Consolidated Financial Statements Statutory Auditors’ report on the consolidated financial statements STATUTORY AUDITORS’ REPORT ON THE CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS (For the year ended 31 December 2018) This is a free translation into English of the Statutory Auditors’ report issued in French and is provided solely for the convenience of English speaking readers. This report includes information specifically required by European regulations or French law, such as information about the appointment of Statutory Auditors. This report should be read in conjunction with, and construed in accordance with, French law and professional auditing standards applicable in France. To the Shareholders, OPINION In compliance with the engagement entrusted to us by your General Meeting of Shareholders, we have audited the accompanying consolidated financial statements of Crédit Agricole S.A. for the year ended 31 December 2018. In our opinion, the consolidated financial statements give a true and fair view of the assets and liabilities and of the financial position of the Group at 31 December 2018 and of the results of its operations for the year then ended in accordance with International Financial Reporting Standards as adopted by the European Union. The audit opinion expressed above is consistent with our report to the Audit Committee. BASIS FOR OPINION Audit framework We conducted our audit in accordance with professional standards applicable in France. We believe that the audit evidence we have obtained is sufficient and appropriate to provide a basis for our opinion. Our responsibilities under these standards are further described in the “Responsibilities of the Statutory Auditors relating to the audit of the consolidated financial statements” section of our report. Independence We conducted our audit engagement in compliance with the independence rules applicable to us, for the period from 1 January 2018 to the date of our report, and, in particular, we did not provide any non audit services prohibited by article 5(1) of Regulation (EU) No 537/2014 or the French Code of Ethics (Code de déontologie) for Statutory Auditors. EMPHASIS OF MATTER Without qualifying our opinion, we draw your attention to the change in accounting policy concerning the application as from 1 January 2018 of the new IFRS 9 “Financial instruments” presented in Note 1.1 “Applicable standards and comparability” and the paragraph “Accounting rules and procedures” as well as in the other notes to the consolidated financial statements presenting quantified data related to the impact of this change. 6 JUSTIFICATION OF ASSESSMENTS – KEY AUDIT MATTERS In accordance with the requirements of articles L. 823-9 and R. 823-7 of the French Commercial Code (Code de commerce) relating to the justification of our assessments, we inform you of the key audit matters relating to the risks of material misstatement that, in our professional judgement, were the most significant in our audit of the consolidated financial statements, as well as how we addressed those risks. These matters were addressed as part of our audit of the consolidated financial statements as a whole, and therefore contributed to the opinion we formed as expressed above. We do not provide a separate opinion on specific items of the consolidated financial statements. The definitions of the underlined words can be found in the Glossary on page 600. Group, For the main specific reserves mentioned below, we included actuaries in insurance liabilities are recognised as technical reserves in compliance with our audit teams, for the purpose of: French consolidation standards and the applicable regulations, as permitted nn examining the compliance of the Group’s methodology for measuring under IFRS 4. these reserves with the applicable regulations; These technical reserves include certain specific reserves required under nn gaining an understanding of the control environment relating to the the French Insurance Code (Code des assurances), the determination of management or valuation of losses, the design of forecast models or which necessitates a particular degree of judgement. This concerns the stochastic models and the determination of the main assumptions input in following reserves in particular: the model (asset yield, modelling of fees, redemption rate, mortality tables, nn in an environment of ongoing low interest rates, the overall management projected period of independent living and probability of occurrence of a expenses reserve established for each homogeneous class of life state of dependency, discount rate, etc.); insurance policies where the management fees charged to policyholders nn reconciling the main data used for calculating these reserves with the do not cover management expenses; management data; nn the reserve for growing risks of dependence, established where the nn analysing certain models or data in the light of market practice, the present value of the insurer’s commitments in terms of health or disability economic environment and historical data; cover is higher than the projected contributions of policyholders; nn examining the key controls of the information systems supporting the nn reserves for late claims relating to non-life insurance policies for which processing of technical data and accounting entries; losses have occurred but have not yet been declared or valued. nn recalculating certain reserves. For the life insurance technical reserves, the Group conducts an annual liability adequacy test to ensure that insurance liabilities are adequate to meet estimated future cash flows after projected management fees. Considering the sensitivity of the above specific reserves and of the liability adequacy test to the different underlying assumptions used (asset yield forecasts, policyholder behaviour, insurer’s financial policy, period of independent living or probability of occurrence of a state of dependency, statistical models and expert assessments used for valuing late claims, discount rate, etc.), we deemed specific technical reserves and liability adequacy tests to be a key audit matter. Net insurance technical reserves amounted to €322.8 billion at 31 December 2018. CRÉDIT AGRICOLE S.A. | 2018 Registration Document 515 6 Consolidated Financial Statements Statutory Auditors’ report on the consolidated financial statements SPECIFIC VERIFICATIONS As required by legal and regulatory provisions and in accordance with professional standards applicable in France, we have also verified the information pertaining to the Group presented in the Board of Directors’ management report. We have no matters to report as to its fair presentation and its consistency with the consolidated financial statements. We attest that the information pertaining to the Group presented in Board of Directors’ management report includes the consolidated non-financial information statement required under article L. 225-102-1 of the French Commercial Code. However, in accordance with article L. 823-10 of the French Commercial Code, we have not verified the fair presentation and consistency with the consolidated financial statements of the information given in that statement, which will be the subject of a report by an independent third party. REPORT ON OTHER LEGAL AND REGULATORY REQUIREMENTS Appointment of the Statutory Auditors We were appointed Statutory Auditors of Crédit Agricole S.A. by the General Meetings of Shareholders held on 19 May 2004 for PricewaterhouseCoopers Audit and in 1985 for Ernst & Young et Autres. At 31 December 2018, PricewaterhouseCoopers Audit and Ernst & Young et Autres were in the fifteenth and the thirty-fourth consecutive year of their engagement, respectively. RESPONSIBILITIES OF MANAGEMENT AND THOSE CHARGED WITH GOVERNANCE FOR THE CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS Management is responsible for preparing consolidated financial statements giving a true and fair view in accordance with International Financial Reporting Standards as adopted by the European Union and for implementing the internal control procedures it deems necessary for the preparation of consolidated financial statements that are free of material misstatement, whether due to fraud or error. In preparing the consolidated financial statements, management is responsible for assessing the Company’s ability to continue as a going concern, disclosing, as applicable, matters related to going concern, and using the going concern basis of accounting, unless it expects to liquidate the Company or to cease operations. The Audit Committee is responsible for monitoring the financial reporting process and the effectiveness of internal control and risk management systems, as well as, where applicable, any internal audit systems, relating to accounting and financial reporting procedures. The consolidated financial statements were approved by the Board of Directors. RESPONSIBILITIES OF THE STATUTORY AUDITORS RELATING TO THE AUDIT OF THE CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS Objective and audit approach Our role is to issue a report on the consolidated financial statements. Our objective is to obtain reasonable assurance about whether the consolidated financial statements as a whole are free of material misstatement. Reasonable assurance is a high level of assurance, but is not a guarantee that an audit conducted in accordance with professional standards will always detect a material misstatement when it exists. Misstatements can arise from fraud or error and are considered material if, individually or in the aggregate, they could reasonably be expected to influence the economic decisions taken by users on the basis of these consolidated financial statements. As specified in article L. 823-10-1 of the French Commercial Code, our audit does not include assurance on the viability or quality of the Company’s management. As part of an audit conducted in accordance with professional standards applicable in France, the Statutory Auditors exercise professional judgement throughout the audit. They also: nn identify and assess the risks of material misstatement in the consolidated financial statements, whether due to fraud or error, design and perform audit procedures in response to those risks, and obtain audit evidence considered to be sufficient and appropriate to provide a basis for their opinion. The risk of not detecting a material misstatement resulting from fraud is higher than for one resulting from error, as fraud may involve collusion, forgery, intentional omissions, misrepresentations, or the override of internal control; nn obtain an understanding of the internal control procedures relevant to the audit in order to design audit procedures that are appropriate in the circumstances, but not for the purpose of expressing an opinion on the effectiveness of the internal control; nn evaluate the appropriateness of accounting policies used and the reasonableness of accounting estimates made by management and the related disclosures in the notes to the consolidated financial statements; 516 CRÉDIT AGRICOLE S.A. | 2018 Registration Document The definitions of the underlined words can be found in the Glossary on page 600. Consolidated Financial Statements Statutory Auditors’ report on the consolidated financial statements nn assess the appropriateness of management’s use of the going concern basis of accounting and, based on the audit evidence obtained, whether a material uncertainty exists related to events or conditions that may cast significant doubt on the Company’s ability to continue as a going concern. This assessment is based on the audit evidence obtained up to the date of the audit report. However, future events or conditions may cause the Company to cease to continue as a going concern. If the Statutory Auditors conclude that a material uncertainty exists, they are required to draw attention in the audit report to the related disclosures in the consolidated financial statements or, if such disclosures are not provided or are inadequate, to issue a qualified opinion or a disclaimer of opinion; nn evaluate the overall presentation of the consolidated financial statements and assess whether these statements represent the underlying transactions and events in a manner that achieves fair presentation; nn obtain sufficient appropriate audit evidence regarding the financial information of the entities or business activities within the Group to express an opinion on the consolidated financial statements. The Statutory Auditors are responsible for the management, supervision and performance of the audit of the consolidated financial statements and for the opinion expressed thereon. Report to the Audit Committee We submit a report to the Audit Committee which includes, in particular, a description of the scope of the audit and the audit programme implemented, as well as the results of our audit. We also report any significant deficiencies in internal control that we have identified regarding the accounting and financial reporting procedures. Our report to the Audit Committee includes the risks of material misstatement that, in our professional judgement, were the most significant for the audit of the consolidated financial statements and which constitute the key audit matters that we are required to describe in this report. We also provide the Audit Committee with the declaration provided for in article 6 of Regulation (EU) No 537/2014, confirming our independence within the meaning of the rules applicable in France, as defined in particular in articles L. 822-10 to L. 822-14 of the French Commercial Code and in the French Code of Ethics for Statutory Auditors. Where appropriate, we discuss any risks to our independence and the related safeguard measures with the Audit Committee. Neuilly-sur-Seine and Paris-La Défense, 25 March 2019 The Statutory Auditors PricewaterhouseCoopers Audit ERNST & YOUNG ET AUTRES Anik Chaumartin Olivier Durand 6 The definitions of the underlined words can be found in the Glossary on page 600. CRÉDIT AGRICOLE S.A. | 2018 Registration Document 527 7 Parent Company Financial Statements Notes to the parent company financial statements Note 2 The application of ANC Regulation 2014-07 of 26 November 2014 led regularly resumed for amounts corresponding to the original contractual Crédit Agricole S.A. to recognise loans with a risk of non-payment in schedule. In this case, the outstanding amount is reclassified under accordance with the rules set out in the following paragraphs. performing loans. The use of external and/or internal ratings systems helps assess the level of credit risk. Impairment resulting from credit risk on doubtful Loans and financing commitments are split into those deemed loans performing and those deemed doubtful. Once a loan is doubtful, the likely loss is recognised by Crédit Agricole S.A. by means of impairment losses deducted from the asset on the Performing loans balance sheet. This impairment represents the difference between the So long as loans are not classified as doubtful, they are classified as carrying amount of the loan and the estimated future flows discounted performing and remain as initially classified. at the effective interest rate, having regard to the financial position of the counterparty, its economic outlook as well as any guarantees net of the cost of realising them. Provisions for credit risk on performing loans Probable losses in respect of off-balance sheet commitments are Moreover, without waiting for loans to become doubtful and from initial covered by provisions recognised as liabilities. recognition of financial instruments, Crédit Agricole S.A. also recognises, Loans and receivables provided by Crédit Agricole S.A. to the Regional on the liabilities side of its balance sheet, expected credit losses for the Banks do not represent a direct risk for Crédit Agricole S.A. with respect coming twelve months (loans classified as performing) and/or over the to the corresponding customer loans made by the Regional Banks. life of the financial instrument whenever the credit quality of the loan They do, however, represent a potential indirect risk with respect to has significantly impaired (loans classified as impaired). the financial strength of the Regional Banks. Crédit Agricole S.A. has Increases and reversals of provisions for credit risk on performing loans not made any provisions for such loans and receivables to the Regional are recognised under cost of risk. Banks. These provisions are determined as part of a specific monitoring process and are based on estimates reflecting changes in the level of credit risk Accounting treatment of impairments on the date of initial recognition and the reporting date. Impairment losses and reversals for non-recovery of doubtful loans are recognised under cost of risk. At 31 December 2018, 1,270 entities had signed tax consolidation The tax charge appearing in the income statement is the corporate agreements with Crédit Agricole S.A. Under these agreements, each income tax due in respect of the financial year. It includes the effect of company that is part of the tax consolidation mechanism recognises the 3.3% additional social contribution on profits. in its financial statements the tax that it would have had to pay in the absence of tax consolidation. When tax credits on income from loans and securities portfolios are effectively used to pay corporate income tax due for the financial year, Given that the legislative intent when introducing the tax credit for they are recognised under the same heading as the income with which competitiveness and employment (Crédit d’Impôt pour la Compétitivité they are associated. The corresponding tax charge continues to be et l’Emploi – CICE) was to reduce employee expenses, Crédit Agricole recognised under “Income tax charge” in the income statement. S.A. chose to recognise the CICE (Article 244 quater C of the French General Tax Code) as a reduction in employee expenses and not as a reduction in tax. 534 CRÉDIT AGRICOLE S.A. | 2018 Registration Document The definitions of the underlined words can be found in the Glossary on page 600. CRÉDIT AGRICOLE S.A. | 2018 Registration Document 559 7 Parent Company Financial Statements Statutory Auditors’ report on the financial statements STATUTORY AUDITORS’ REPORT ON THE FINANCIAL STATEMENTS (For the year ended 31 December 2018) This is a free translation into English of the Statutory Auditors’ report issued in French and is provided solely for the convenience of English speaking readers. This report includes information specifically required by European regulations or French law, such as information about the appointment of Statutory Auditors. This report should be read in conjunction with, and construed in accordance with, French law and professional auditing standards applicable in France. To the Shareholders, OPINION In compliance with the engagement entrusted to us by your General Meeting of Shareholders, we have audited the accompanying financial statements of Crédit Agricole S.A. for the year ended 31 December 2018. In our opinion, the financial statements give a true and fair view of the assets and liabilities and of the financial position of the Company at 31 December 2018 and of the results of its operations for the year then ended in accordance with French accounting principles. The audit opinion expressed above is consistent with our report to the Audit Committee. BASIS FOR OPINION Audit framework We conducted our audit in accordance with professional standards applicable in France. We believe that the audit evidence we have obtained is sufficient and appropriate to provide a basis for our opinion. Our responsibilities under these standards are further described in the “Responsibilities of the Statutory Auditors relating to the audit of the financial statements” section of our report. Independence We conducted our audit engagement in compliance with the independence rules applicable to us, for the period from 1 January 2018 to the date of our report, and, in particular, we did not provide any non-audit services prohibited by article 5(1) of Regulation (EU) No 537/2014 or the French Code of Ethics (Code de déontologie) for Statutory Auditors. EMPHASIS OF MATTER Without qualifying our opinion, we draw your attention to the changes in accounting policy presented in Note 2 “Accounting rules and procedures” to the financial statements with respect to: nn new ANC regulations or amendments to existing ANC regulations; nn the new credit risk provisioning model for performing loans, designed to transpose the new credit risk provisioning model introduced by IFRS 9 for expected credit losses in the financial statements as from 1 January 2018. JUSTIFICATION OF ASSESSMENTS – KEY AUDIT MATTERS In accordance with the requirements of articles L. 823-9 and R. 823-7 of the French Commercial Code (Code de commerce) relating to the justification of our assessments, we inform you of the key audit matters relating to the risks of material misstatement that, in our professional judgement, were the most significant in our audit of the financial statements, as well as how we addressed those risks. These matters were addressed as part of our audit of the financial statements as a whole, and therefore contributed to the opinion we formed as expressed above. We do not provide a separate opinion on specific items of the financial statements. 560 CRÉDIT AGRICOLE S.A. | 2018 Registration Document The definitions of the underlined words can be found in the Glossary on page 600. CRÉDIT AGRICOLE S.A. | 2018 Registration Document 561 7 Parent Company Financial Statements Statutory Auditors’ report on the financial statements SPECIFIC VERIFICATIONS In accordance with professional standards applicable in France, we have also performed the specific verifications required by French legal and regulatory provisions. Information given in the management report and in the other documents provided to the shareholders with respect to the Company’s financial position and the financial statements We have no matters to report as to the fair presentation and the consistency with the financial statements of the information given in the Board of Directors’ management report and in the other documents provided to the shareholders with respect to the Company’s financial position and the financial statements, with the exception of the following matter. Concerning the fair presentation and the consistency with the financial statements of the disclosures provided in relation to the payment terms referred to in article D. 441-4 of the French Commercial Code, we have the following matter to report: as indicated in the management report, these disclosures do not include banking and related transactions as the Company considers that such disclosures are not within the scope of disclosures to be provided. Report on corporate governance We attest that the Board of Directors’ report on corporate governance sets out the information required by articles L. 225-37-3 and L. 225-37-4 of the French Commercial Code. Concerning the information given in accordance with the requirements of article L. 225-37-3 of the French Commercial Code relating to remuneration and benefits received by corporate officers and any other commitments made in their favour, we have verified its consistency with the financial statements or with the underlying information used to prepare these financial statements, and, where applicable, with the information obtained by your Company from companies controlling it or controlled by it. Based on this work, we attest to the accuracy and fair presentation of this information. Concerning the information given in accordance with the requirements of article L. 225-37-5 of the French Commercial Code relating to those items your Company has deemed liable to have an impact in the event of a takeover bid or exchange offer, we have verified its consistency with the underlying documents that were disclosed to us. Based on this work, we have no matters to report with regard to this information. Other information In accordance with French law, we have verified that the required information concerning the acquisition of investments and controlling interests and the identity of shareholders and holders of the voting rights has been properly disclosed in the management report. REPORT ON OTHER LEGAL AND REGULATORY REQUIREMENTS Appointment of the Statutory Auditors We were appointed Statutory Auditors of Crédit Agricole S.A. by the General Meetings of Shareholders held on 19 May 2004 for PricewaterhouseCoopers Audit and in 1985 for ERNST & YOUNG et Autres. At 31 December 2018, PricewaterhouseCoopers Audit and Ernst & Young et Autres were in the fifteenth and the thirty-fourth consecutive year of their engagement, respectively. RESPONSIBILITIES OF MANAGEMENT AND THOSE CHARGED WITH GOVERNANCE FOR THE FINANCIAL STATEMENTS Management is responsible for preparing financial statements giving a true and fair view in accordance with French accounting principles, and for implementing the internal control procedures it deems necessary for the preparation of financial statements that are free of material misstatement, whether due to fraud or error. In preparing the financial statements, management is responsible for assessing the Company’s ability to continue as a going concern, disclosing, as applicable, matters related to going concern, and using the going concern basis of accounting, unless it expects to liquidate the Company or to cease operations. The Audit Committee is responsible for monitoring the financial reporting process and the effectiveness of internal control and risk management systems, as well as, where applicable, any internal audit systems, relating to accounting and financial reporting procedures. The financial statements were approved by the Board of Directors. 562 CRÉDIT AGRICOLE S.A. | 2018 Registration Document The definitions of the underlined words can be found in the Glossary on page 600. Parent Company Financial Statements Statutory Auditors’ report on the financial statements RESPONSIBILITIES OF THE STATUTORY AUDITORS RELATING TO THE AUDIT OF THE FINANCIAL STATEMENTS Objective and audit approach Our role is to issue a report on the financial statements. Our objective is to obtain reasonable assurance about whether the financial statements as a whole are free of material misstatement. Reasonable assurance is a high level of assurance, but is not a guarantee that an audit conducted in accordance with professional standards will always detect a material misstatement when it exists. Misstatements can arise from fraud or error and are considered material if, individually or in the aggregate, they could reasonably be expected to influence the economic decisions taken by users on the basis of these financial statements. As specified in article L. 823-10-1 of the French Commercial Code, our audit does not include assurance on the viability or quality of the Company’s management. As part of an audit conducted in accordance with professional standards applicable in France, the Statutory Auditors exercise professional judgement throughout the audit. They also: nn identify and assess the risks of material misstatement in the financial statements, whether due to fraud or error, design and perform audit procedures in response to those risks, and obtain audit evidence considered to be sufficient and appropriate to provide a basis for their opinion. The risk of not detecting a material misstatement resulting from fraud is higher than for one resulting from error, as fraud may involve collusion, forgery, intentional omissions, misrepresentations, or the override of internal control; nn obtain an understanding of the internal control procedures relevant to the audit in order to design audit procedures that are appropriate in the circumstances, but not for the purpose of expressing an opinion on the effectiveness of the internal control; nn evaluate the appropriateness of accounting policies used and the reasonableness of accounting estimates made by management and the related disclosures in the notes to the financial statements; nn assess the appropriateness of management’s use of the going concern basis of accounting and, based on the audit evidence obtained, whether a material uncertainty exists related to events or conditions that may cast significant doubt on the Company’s ability to continue as a going concern. This assessment is based on the audit evidence obtained up to the date of the audit report. However, future events or conditions may cause the Company to cease to continue as a going concern. If the Statutory Auditors conclude that a material uncertainty exists, they are required to draw attention in the audit report to the related disclosures in the financial statements or, if such disclosures are not provided or are inadequate, to issue a qualified opinion or a disclaimer of opinion; nn evaluate the overall presentation of the financial statements and assess whether these statements represent the underlying transactions and events in a manner that achieves fair presentation. Report to the Audit Committee We submit a report to the Audit Committee which includes, in particular, a description of the scope of the audit and the audit programme implemented, as well as the results of our audit. We also report any significant deficiencies in internal control that we have identified regarding the accounting and financial reporting procedures Our report to the Audit Committee includes the risks of material misstatement that, in our professional judgement, were the most significant for the audit of the financial statements and which constitute the key audit matters that we are required to describe in this report. We also provide the Audit Committee with the declaration provided for in article 6 of Regulation (EU) No 537/2014, confirming our independence within the meaning of the rules applicable in France, as defined in particular in articles L. 822-10 to L. 822-14 of the French Commercial Code and in the French Code of Ethics for Statutory Auditors. Where appropriate, we discuss any risks to our independence and the related safeguard measures with the Audit Committee.
